††institutetext: School of Mathematics, Statistics and Physics, Newcastle University, Newcastle Upon Tyne, NE1 7RU, UK

Gravitational corrections to Higgs potentials.

Marios Bounakis M.Bounakis2@newcastle.ac.uk    Ian G. Moss ian.moss@ncl.ac.uk
Abstract

Understanding the Higgs potential at large field values corresponding to scales in the range above 1010​GeVsuperscript1010GeV10^{10}{\rm GeV} is important for questions of vacuum stability, particularly in the early universe where survival of the Higgs vacuum can be an issue. In this paper we show that the Higgs potential can be derived in away which is independent of the choice of conformal frame for the spacetime metric. Questions about vacuum stability can therefore be answered unambiguously. We show that frame independence leads to new relations between the beta functions of the theory and we give improved limits on the allowed values of the Higgs curvature coupling for stability.

1 introduction

Extrapolation of the Standard Model of particle physics to high energies leads to the remarkable conclusion that our vacuum is only a long-lived metastable state, in which the Higgs field sits at a local minimum of the Higgs potential surrounded by a potential barrier of width somewhere in the range 1010−1014​GeVsuperscript1010superscript1014GeV10^{10}-10^{14}{\rm GeV} Degrassi:2012ry ; Buttazzo:2013uya ; Blum:2015rpa . This raises an interesting question about initial conditions, because, if the Standard Model is correct at these energies, then somehow the Higgs field had to evolve into the metastable vacuum state during the early stages of the universe Espinosa:2007qp .

The Higgs potential barrier depends strongly on the effective Higgs mass at high energies, and it is quite possible that gravitational corrections may be important. In the relevant energy range, there is no reason to abandon General Relativity as ‘an effective field theory’ description of gravity Burgess:2003jk . There are two contributions to the effective Higgs mass, the ordinary one and the mass due to the coupling ξ​R​ℋ†​ℋ𝜉𝑅superscriptℋ†ℋ\xi R{\cal H}^{\dagger}{\cal H}, between the Higgs field ℋℋ{\cal H} and the curvature R𝑅R. We will assume that inflation is driven by an inflaton field, not the Higgs field, which is assumed weakly interacting and makes no contribution to the Higgs potential. The curvature coupling increases the height of the potential barrier around the metastable minimum if ξ​R𝜉𝑅\xi R is positive, and has the opposite effect when ξ​R𝜉𝑅\xi R is negative, making Higgs stability sensitive to the value of ξ𝜉\xi.

Placing the Higgs decay into a cosmological context introduces an ambiguity in how we define the spacetime geometry. In particular, we can perform a conformal re-scaling of the metric which removes the curvature-coupling term, transforming the theory from the original Jordan frame metric to the Einstein frame metric. It has been noted that quantum calculations can sometimes lead to different results when done in the Jordan or the Einstein frame George:2013iia ; Steinwachs:2013tr . This is a puzzle, because we want to avoid a situation in which the Higgs field is unstable in the Jordan frame and stable in the Einstein frame. The contradiction would be best resolved by having an approach to quantisation which is consistent whatever the choice of spacetime metric Kamenshchik:2014waa ; George:2015nza ; Moss:2014nya ; Moss:2015gua . We shall show that there is a covariant quantisation scheme which gives consistent results on Higgs instability.

The basic tool we use is an effective action which is covariant under field transformations Vilkovisky:1984 ; DeWittdynamical ; barvinsky1985generalized ; ParkerTomsbook . This is a stronger requirement than General Covariance, or covariance under spacetime coordinate transformations. The idea of a field-space covariant quantum field theory (hereafter called covariant) is illustrated by the diagram in Eq (1). Quantisation followed by a field redefinition should give the same result as starting from a field redefinition and then quantising, i.e. the diagram should commute.

φ→φ′↓↓Γ​[φ]→Γ​[φ′]matrix𝜑→superscript𝜑′↓missing-subexpression↓Γdelimited-[]𝜑→Γdelimited-[]superscript𝜑′\begin{matrix}\varphi&\to&\varphi^{\prime}\\ \downarrow&&\downarrow\\ \Gamma[\varphi]&\to&\Gamma[\varphi^{\prime}]\\ \end{matrix} (1)

Demanding covariance of the effective action guarantees covariance of the effective field equations. Without covariance, there is a different quantum field theory for each choice of field variables. Imposing covariance has another virtue. Terms are added to the classical Lagrangian to fix the gauge freedom. Solutions to the usual effective field equations depend on the choice of these gauge-fixing terms. However, in the covariant approach, the solutions to the effective field equations are independent of the gauge-fixing terms.

Covariant approaches are widely used to quantise non-linear sigma models AlvarezGaume198185 ; Howe:1986vm , but they are very rarely used for gauge theories. One reason they are not widely used is that the gauge-fixing dependence of the usual effective action is not considered problematic, since the dependence goes away ‘on-shell’ , i.e. the action takes the same value at solutions to the effective field equations Nielsen1975 ; Fukuda1976 ; Kobes:1991 ; Contreras:1996nx . Furthermore, it is easy to show that the Jordan and Einstein frame Higgs theories have equivalent perturbative expansions when the background fields are on-shell and the Higgs field is small Markkanen:2017dlc .

Using a covariant approach retains the gauge-fixing and frame independence off-shell, for any range of Higgs field. On the other hand, covariant approaches are not totally unambiguous, because there are two versions of the covariant effective action: Γ​[φ∗,φ]Γsuperscript𝜑𝜑\Gamma[\varphi^{*},\varphi] which generates the 1PI diagrams but depends on an extra field φ∗superscript𝜑\varphi^{*} Burgess:1987zi , and the DeWitt effective action Γ​[φ]Γdelimited-[]𝜑\Gamma[\varphi] which does not generate 1PI diagrams DeWitt2 . Fortunately, both generate the same effective field equations, and they agree on-shell. They are therefore equivalent for questions of vacuum stability, so we will use the simpler DeWitt effective action.

Higgs vacuum decay is a situation where the effective action and the classical action lead to very different qualitative behaviour Krive:1977 ; Polizer:1979 ; Cabibbo:1979ay ; Sher:1988mj . Another example is Coleman-Weinberg theory of massless electrodynamics, where quantum corrections to the effective action lead to symmetry breaking. In these situations, we use solutions to the renormalisation group corrected field equations with running coupling constants to determine the vacuum state or to calculate tunnelling amplitudes coleman . Note that we use ‘on shell’ to refer to fields which satisfy the effective field equations rather than the classical field equations. We will investigate whether covariant and non-covariant approaches to the effective action give different physical results by doing specific calculations of the running couplings in the Higgs effective potential.

The renormalisation group corrected potential used here is constructed as follows. The DeWitt effective action for the modulus of the Higgs field ϕitalic-ϕ\phi is written as a functional Γ​(gi,ϕ,gμ​ν,μR)Γsubscript𝑔𝑖italic-ϕsubscript𝑔𝜇𝜈subscript𝜇𝑅\Gamma(g_{i},\phi,g_{\mu\nu},\mu_{R}), where gisubscript𝑔𝑖g_{i} are running couplings depending on μRsubscript𝜇𝑅\mu_{R}, the renormalisation scale. At one loop order, the explicit dependence on renormalisation scale has contributions from all types of field in the standard model. These contributions are determined by perturbation theory and depend on a set of second order differential operators Δn​(ϕ)superscriptΔ𝑛italic-ϕ\Delta^{n}(\phi). Following Coleman and Weinberg coleman , the β𝛽\beta functions can be obtained by comparing coefficients in the renormalisation group equation for the Lagrangian,

∑iβi​∂ℒ∂gi−γϕ​ϕ​∂ℒ∂ϕ−γg​gμ​ν​∂ℒ∂gμ​ν=116​π2​∑n(±)​b2​(Δn),subscript𝑖subscript𝛽𝑖ℒsubscript𝑔𝑖subscript𝛾italic-ϕitalic-ϕℒitalic-ϕsubscript𝛾𝑔subscript𝑔𝜇𝜈ℒsubscript𝑔𝜇𝜈116superscript𝜋2subscript𝑛plus-or-minussubscript𝑏2superscriptΔ𝑛\sum_{i}\beta_{i}{\partial{\cal L}\over\partial g_{i}}-\gamma_{\phi}\phi{\partial{\cal L}\over\partial\phi}-\gamma_{g}g_{\mu\nu}{\partial{\cal L}\over\partial g_{\mu\nu}}={1\over 16\pi^{2}}\sum_{n}(\pm)b_{2}(\Delta^{n}), (2)

where the sign is positive for bosons and negative for fermions and ghosts. Renormalisation of the fields is responsible for the anomalous dimensions γϕsubscript𝛾italic-ϕ\gamma_{\phi} and γgsubscript𝛾𝑔\gamma_{g} (where we are using the sign conventions of Sher:1988mj ). The functions b2subscript𝑏2b_{2} are polynomial combinations of coefficients in the operators ΔnsuperscriptΔ𝑛\Delta^{n}. General expressions for b2subscript𝑏2b_{2} are known for many types of operators on arbitrary spacetime backgrounds (e.g. Vassilevich:2003xt ). Since the theory we are dealing with is not renormalisable, the Lagrangian has an infinite series of terms which has to be truncated at some inverse power of the the cutoff scale of the theory, which we naturally take to be the Planck mass. At one loop, the b2subscript𝑏2b_{2} coefficient gives us terms up to order Mp−4superscriptsubscript𝑀𝑝4M_{p}^{-4}.

A change of variable from μRsubscript𝜇𝑅\mu_{R} to t=ln⁡(ϕ/μR)𝑡italic-ϕsubscript𝜇𝑅t=\ln(\phi/\mu_{R}) changes the functional form of the couplings in the effective action from gi​(μR)subscript𝑔𝑖subscript𝜇𝑅g_{i}(\mu_{R}) to gi′​(t)superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑖′𝑡g_{i}^{\prime}(t),

Γ′​(gi′​(t),ϕ′​(t),gμ​ν′​(t),t)=Γ​(gi​(μR),ϕ​(μR),gμ​ν​(μR),μR).superscriptΓ′subscriptsuperscript𝑔′𝑖𝑡superscriptitalic-ϕ′𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝑔′𝜇𝜈𝑡𝑡Γsubscript𝑔𝑖subscript𝜇𝑅italic-ϕsubscript𝜇𝑅subscript𝑔𝜇𝜈subscript𝜇𝑅subscript𝜇𝑅\Gamma^{\prime}(g^{\prime}_{i}(t),\phi^{\prime}(t),g^{\prime}_{\mu\nu}(t),t)=\Gamma(g_{i}(\mu_{R}),\phi(\mu_{R}),g_{\mu\nu}(\mu_{R}),\mu_{R}). (3)

The renormalisation group corrected Lagrangian is defined by the leading term, ℒ′​(gi′​(t),ϕ′​(t),gμ​ν′​(t))superscriptℒ′subscriptsuperscript𝑔′𝑖𝑡superscriptitalic-ϕ′𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝑔′𝜇𝜈𝑡{\cal L}^{\prime}(g^{\prime}_{i}(t),\phi^{\prime}(t),g^{\prime}_{\mu\nu}(t)). The dependence of the parameters on the Higgs field on ϕitalic-ϕ\phi is determined by the renormalisation group, which implies

d​gi′d​t=βi​(gj′)1+γϕ​(gj′),𝑑subscriptsuperscript𝑔′𝑖𝑑𝑡subscript𝛽𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑔′𝑗1subscript𝛾italic-ϕsubscriptsuperscript𝑔′𝑗{dg^{\prime}_{i}\over dt}={\beta_{i}(g^{\prime}_{j})\over 1+\gamma_{\phi}(g^{\prime}_{j})}, (4)

subject to values fixed at a given (low energy) mass scale M𝑀M.

The first thing to note about the Coleman-Weinberg method for calculating the β𝛽\beta functions is that it relies on the functional form of the effective action. Therefore a knowledge of the effective action which is only valid for solutions to the background field equations is not sufficient. The covariant effective action gives us an unambiguous off-shell formulation and a unique set of beta functions. In order to construct this covariant effective action we make use of the non-trivial geometry of the space of metrics and fields. In the general case of a gauge theory with fields φIsuperscript𝜑𝐼\varphi^{I} and action S​[φ]𝑆delimited-[]𝜑S[\varphi], the covariant operator ΔI​JsubscriptΔ𝐼𝐽\Delta_{IJ} for the field fluctuations is given by Vilkovisky:1984 ; DeWittdynamical

ΔI​J=−δ2​Sδ​φI​δ​φJ+ΓK​δ​Sδ​φKI​J+λg​RI​α​[φ]​RI​α​[φ],subscriptΔ𝐼𝐽superscript𝛿2𝑆𝛿superscript𝜑𝐼𝛿superscript𝜑𝐽superscriptΓ𝐾subscript𝛿𝑆𝛿superscript𝜑𝐾𝐼𝐽subscript𝜆𝑔superscript𝑅𝐼𝛼delimited-[]𝜑subscript𝑅𝐼𝛼delimited-[]𝜑\Delta_{IJ}=-{\delta^{2}S\over\delta\varphi^{I}\delta\varphi^{J}}+\Gamma^{K}{}_{IJ}{\delta S\over\delta\varphi^{K}}+\lambda_{g}R^{I\alpha}[\varphi]R_{I\alpha}[\varphi], (5)

The innovation of Vilkovisky and DeWitt was to put the second functional derivatives into covariant form by introducing a field-space connection ∇Isubscript∇𝐼\nabla_{I} with connection coefficients ΓKI​J\Gamma^{K}{}_{IJ}. The connection ensures that the effective action is covariant under field redefinitions. In the Landau gauge limit λg→∞→subscript𝜆𝑔\lambda_{g}\to\infty, the connection coefficients reduce to the Levi-Civita connection coefficients for the local metric on the space of fields. The final term in (5) is a gauge-fixing term. Details of the covariant approach are given in Sect 2

The connection term vanishes when the background field satisfies the classical field equations i.e. δ​S/δ​φI=0𝛿𝑆𝛿superscript𝜑𝐼0\delta S/\delta\varphi^{I}=0, and then non-covariant and covariant effective actions agree. However, we might expect differing results when the background satisfies the quantum corrected field equations. The beta-functions and the renormalisation group corrected effective Lagrangians defined using non-covariant and covariant approaches need not be the same.

In Sects. 4 and 5 we will calculate the Higgs parameter beta-functions in both covariant and non-covariant form in the Einstein and Jordan frames. As is well known, the beta-function for the curvature coupling βξ∝6​ξ−1proportional-tosubscript𝛽𝜉6𝜉1\beta_{\xi}\propto 6\xi-1 in the Jordan frame. This standard result cannot hold in a covariant approach, because ξ𝜉\xi vanishes in the Einstein frame and therefore the covariant βξsubscript𝛽𝜉\beta_{\xi} cannot depend on ξ𝜉\xi. 111In fact, ξ𝜉\xi appears as a correction to the mass in the Einstein frame, and contributes to βμ2subscript𝛽superscript𝜇2\beta_{\mu^{2}}. As expected, when we do the calculation, the non-covariant results are frame dependent whilst the covariant results are frame independent. However, the combination μ2+ξ​Rsuperscript𝜇2𝜉𝑅\mu^{2}+\xi R, which acts as an effective Higgs mass, and the Higgs self-coupling λ𝜆\lambda have the same scale behaviour in non-covariant and covariant approaches. The leading behaviour of the renormalisation group effective potential is therefore frame independent, and differences arise only in terms that are suppressed by factors of Mp−4superscriptsubscript𝑀𝑝4M_{p}^{-4}. Our results for stability with the renormalisation group corrected potential are therefore similar to those found previously Herranen:2014cua .

In Sect. 4 we will explore some of the consequences of the covariant approach. One of these is that field redefinitions mix some of the parameters of the theory, and having covariance leads to a set of relations between the beta functions for these parameters. These relations can be used, for example, to completely determine the dependence of the beta-functions on the curvature coupling ξ𝜉\xi. Another consequence of using a covariant approach is that the path integral is independent of the gauge-fixing terms in the Lagrangian. Therefore quantum tunnelling rates will be unambiguous. In non-covariant approaches, this issue is non-trivial, and independence has only been demonstrated explicitly when the true vacuum is not radiatively generated Plascencia:2015pga ; Endo:2017gal .

In Sect. 7, we look at a practical application of our results to the decay of the Higgs vacuum during inflation. The running couplings make a considerable difference to the Higgs decay rates when the curvature coupling is small. This is consistent with earlier work by Herranen et al. Herranen:2014cua , but we give more precise results and we confirm that the results are the same in both the Jordan and Einstein frame. We also find a regime in which the Higgs potential has two maxima. We only consider vacuum decay using tunnelling with the simplest type of instanton, thought recent work has shown the existence of more complicated instanton solutions Rajantie:2017ajw .

This paper focuses on the UV behaviour of the quantum theory and how this affects the Higgs potential in de Sitter space. In many ways, though, the IR behaviour of Higgs fields in de Sitter space is a more interesting subject. It has become apparent, initially from stochastic theory Starobinsky:1994bd ; Burgess:2009bs ; Garbrecht:2011gu ; Serreau:2011fu and also from infra-red expansions Rajaraman:2010xd ; Beneke:2012kn , that a self-coupled massless scalar field in a de Sitter invariant state acquires a mass squared of order λ1/2​H2superscript𝜆12superscript𝐻2\lambda^{1/2}H^{2}, where H𝐻H is the expansion rate. This limits the applicability of our results for small curvature coupling. It also means that, when integrating the renormalisation group equations for the effective mass in de Sitter space, we start with this IR mass, rather than the low energy Higgs mass.

2 Covariant effective actions

The aim of this section is to introduce the field-covariant effective action and to give two methods for evaluating the action to one loop order, specifically by taking the Landau gauge-fixing limit and by decomposition into gauge-fixed and pure gauge modes, leading to the results quoted in the introduction. Field components are denoted by indices I,J,…𝐼𝐽…I,J,\dots and gauge parameters by indices α,β,…𝛼𝛽…\alpha,\beta,\dots. Condensed notation is used throughout, with contractions over I,J,…𝐼𝐽…I,J,\dots denoting integration over spacetime and functional derivatives with respect to the fields denoted by ∂Isubscript𝐼\partial_{I}.

A field-covariant effective action can be constructed whenever there exists a covariant notion of the distance between two field configurations. Formally, this means we have a Riemannian geometry on the space of fields φIsuperscript𝜑𝐼\varphi^{I} and geodesics can be defined Vilkovisky:1984 ; DeWittdynamical ; ParkerTomsbook . This geometry allows us to replace an ordinary field displacement φI−ϕIsuperscript𝜑𝐼superscriptitalic-ϕ𝐼\varphi^{I}-\phi^{I} with the covariant tangent vector to the geodesic from ϕIsuperscriptitalic-ϕ𝐼\phi^{I} to φIsuperscript𝜑𝐼\varphi^{I}, which we denote by σI​(ϕ,φ)superscript𝜎𝐼italic-ϕ𝜑\sigma^{I}(\phi,\varphi). The metric can also be used to define a field-space invariant volume measure D​φ𝐷𝜑D\varphi for functional integration.

Our starting point is the covariant action of Burgess and Kunstatter Burgess:1987zi ; ParkerTomsbook , defined implicitly by,

ei​Γ​[ϕ,ϕ∗]=∫D​φ​ei​S​[φ]−i​(δ​Γ/δ​σJ)​(σJ​[ϕ∗,ϕ]−σJ​[ϕ∗,φ]).superscript𝑒𝑖Γitalic-ϕsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝐷𝜑superscript𝑒𝑖𝑆delimited-[]𝜑𝑖𝛿Γ𝛿superscript𝜎𝐽superscript𝜎𝐽subscriptitalic-ϕitalic-ϕsuperscript𝜎𝐽subscriptitalic-ϕ𝜑e^{i\Gamma[\phi,\phi_{*}]}=\int D\varphi\,e^{iS[\varphi]-i(\delta\Gamma/\delta\sigma^{J})(\sigma^{J}[\phi_{*},\phi]-\sigma^{J}[\phi_{*},\varphi])}. (6)

This depends on the effective field ϕIsuperscriptitalic-ϕ𝐼\phi^{I} and an arbitrary expansion point ϕ∗Isuperscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝐼\phi_{*}^{I}. The effective action generates effective field equations for ϕIsuperscriptitalic-ϕ𝐼\phi^{I}, in the the sense that

∂IΓ​[ϕ,ϕ∗]=0⟹⟨σ​[ϕ,φ^]⟩=0,subscript𝐼Γitalic-ϕsubscriptitalic-ϕ0delimited-⟨⟩𝜎italic-ϕ^𝜑0\partial_{I}\Gamma[\phi,\phi_{*}]=0\implies\langle\sigma[\phi,\hat{\varphi}]\rangle=0, (7)

where σ​[ϕ,φ^]𝜎italic-ϕ^𝜑\sigma[\phi,\hat{\varphi}] is the geodesic distance and φ^Isuperscript^𝜑𝐼\hat{\varphi}^{I} is the field operator. In the covariant approach, ϕI≠⟨φ^I⟩superscriptitalic-ϕ𝐼delimited-⟨⟩superscript^𝜑𝐼\phi^{I}\neq\langle\hat{\varphi}^{I}\rangle, but instead ϕIsuperscriptitalic-ϕ𝐼\phi^{I} is the classical field which is closest to the quantum field using the invariant distance. Note that the effective field equations do not depend on the expansion point ϕ∗subscriptitalic-ϕ\phi_{*}. We make use of this fact and choose ϕ∗I=ϕIsubscriptsuperscriptitalic-ϕ𝐼superscriptitalic-ϕ𝐼\phi^{I}_{*}=\phi^{I}, which defines the DeWitt effective action DeWitt2 ; ParkerTomsbook ,

Γ​[ϕ]=Γ​[ϕ,ϕ]Γdelimited-[]italic-ϕΓitalic-ϕitalic-ϕ\Gamma[\phi]=\Gamma[\phi,\phi] (8)

The DeWitt effective action generates the effective field equations using ∂IΓ​[ϕ]=0subscript𝐼Γdelimited-[]italic-ϕ0\partial_{I}\Gamma[\phi]=0.

In a gauge theory, there are infinitesimal gauge transformations of the field φIsuperscript𝜑𝐼\varphi^{I} of the form

δ​φI=RI​ϵαα,𝛿superscript𝜑𝐼superscript𝑅𝐼subscriptsuperscriptitalic-ϵ𝛼𝛼\delta\varphi^{I}=R^{I}{}_{\alpha}\epsilon^{\alpha}, (9)

which leave the action invariant, i.e. RI​∂Iα⁡S=0superscript𝑅𝐼subscriptsubscript𝐼𝛼𝑆0R^{I}{}_{\alpha}\partial_{I}S=0. The gauge is fixed using a gauge-fixing functional χα​[ϕ,φ]superscript𝜒𝛼italic-ϕ𝜑\chi^{\alpha}[\phi,\varphi], and then the path integral is modified as follows,

S[φ]→S[φ]+12γα​βχαχβ+ℏitrlnQα,βS[\varphi]\to S[\varphi]+\frac{1}{2}\gamma_{\alpha\beta}\chi^{\alpha}\chi^{\beta}+{\hbar\over i}{\rm tr}\ln\,Q^{\alpha}{}_{\beta}, (10)

This introduces a metric γα​βsubscript𝛾𝛼𝛽\gamma_{\alpha\beta} on the gauge parameters and a ghost operator

Qα=β(∂Iχα)RI.βQ^{\alpha}{}_{\beta}=(\partial_{I}\chi^{\alpha})R^{I}{}_{\beta}. (11)

Next, a procedure developed by Vilkovisky and DeWitt Vilkovisky:1984 generates the geometry on field space which guarantees that the effective action is:

  1. 1.

    Covariant under field redefinitions of φIsuperscript𝜑𝐼\varphi^{I};

  2. 2.

    Independent of the choice of gauge fixing functional χαsuperscript𝜒𝛼\chi^{\alpha};

  3. 3.

    Independent of the metric γα​βsubscript𝛾𝛼𝛽\gamma_{\alpha\beta}.

The field-space geometry includes a local field-space metric 𝒢I​Jsubscript𝒢𝐼𝐽{\cal G}_{IJ} and a non-local field space connection ∇Isubscript∇𝐼\nabla_{I}. The metric allows an orthogonal decomposition of field variations into pure gauge and gauge-fixed directions. Projection in the pure-gauge direction can be done using

Π¯I=JRI𝒩α​βαRJ​β,\overline{\Pi}^{I}{}_{J}=R^{I}{}_{\alpha}{\cal N}^{\alpha\beta}R_{J\beta}, (12)

where indices are lowered using the metric tensors in the usual way, and the normalisation factor appearing here is

𝒩α​β=(RI​RI​βα)−1.superscript𝒩𝛼𝛽superscriptsuperscript𝑅𝐼subscriptsubscript𝑅𝐼𝛽𝛼1{\cal N}^{\alpha\beta}=(R^{I}{}_{\alpha}R_{I\beta})^{-1}. (13)

When this is applied to a gauge variation, Π¯I​δJ​φJ=δ​φIsuperscript¯Π𝐼subscript𝛿𝐽superscript𝜑𝐽𝛿superscript𝜑𝐼\overline{\Pi}^{I}{}_{J}\delta\varphi^{J}=\delta\varphi^{I}. The orthogonal projection in the gauge-fixed direction is the DeWitt projection Π=𝕀−Π¯Π𝕀¯Π\Pi=\mathbb{I}-\overline{\Pi}.

The local metric also generates a Levy-Civita connection on field space, denoted by 𝒟Isubscript𝒟𝐼{\cal D}_{I}, for example

𝒟I​𝒟J​S=∂I∂JS−ΓK​∂KI​J⁡S.subscript𝒟𝐼subscript𝒟𝐽𝑆subscript𝐼subscript𝐽𝑆superscriptΓ𝐾subscriptsubscript𝐾𝐼𝐽𝑆{\cal D}_{I}{\cal D}_{J}S=\partial_{I}\partial_{J}S-\Gamma^{K}{}_{IJ}\partial_{K}S. (14)

In a gauge theory, the Vilkovisky-DeWitt connection ∇Isubscript∇𝐼\nabla_{I} is not equal to the Levy-Civita connection, but it is related to it by the projection operators,

∇I∇J⁡S=Π​(𝒟I​𝒟J​S)​Π.superscript∇𝐼subscript∇𝐽𝑆Πsuperscript𝒟𝐼subscript𝒟𝐽𝑆Π\nabla^{I}\nabla_{J}S=\Pi({\cal D}^{I}{\cal D}_{J}S)\Pi. (15)

One of the disadvantages of using a covariant approach is that this expression is non-local. However, we will now describe ways to deal with this non-locality at one loop.

At one-loop, the contribution to the covariant effective action obtained from a geodesic expansion of the fields in the path integral is

Γ(1)=ℏ2​itrln{Π(𝒟I𝒟JS)Π+(∂Iχα)(∂Jχα)}−ℏitrlnQα,β\Gamma^{(1)}={\hbar\over 2i}{\rm tr}\ln\left\{\Pi({\cal D}^{I}{\cal D}_{J}S)\Pi+(\partial^{I}\chi^{\alpha})(\partial_{J}\chi_{\alpha})\right\}-{\hbar\over i}{\rm tr}\ln Q^{\alpha}{}_{\beta}, (16)

For an actual calculation, we can reduce the amount of work by choosing a convenient gauge-fixing functional, in particular the ℛξsubscriptℛ𝜉{\cal R}_{\xi} gauges in which ∂Iχα=λg1/2RIα\partial_{I}\chi^{\alpha}=\lambda_{g}^{1/2}R_{I}{}^{\alpha}, where λgsubscript𝜆𝑔\lambda_{g} is a constant gauge-fixing parameter. The one-loop effective action is then

Γ(1)=ℏ2​i​tr​ln⁡{Π​(𝒟I​𝒟J​S)​Π+λg​RI​α​RJ​α}−ℏi​tr​ln⁡{λg1/2​RI​α​RI​β}.superscriptΓ1Planck-constant-over-2-pi2𝑖trΠsuperscript𝒟𝐼subscript𝒟𝐽𝑆Πsubscript𝜆𝑔superscript𝑅𝐼𝛼subscript𝑅𝐽𝛼Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝑖trsuperscriptsubscript𝜆𝑔12superscript𝑅𝐼𝛼subscript𝑅𝐼𝛽\Gamma^{(1)}={\hbar\over 2i}{\rm tr}\ln\left\{\Pi({\cal D}^{I}{\cal D}_{J}S)\Pi+\lambda_{g}R^{I\alpha}R_{J\alpha}\right\}-{\hbar\over i}{\rm tr}\ln\left\{\lambda_{g}^{1/2}R^{I\alpha}R_{I\beta}\right\}. (17)

If the covariant derivatives in (14) are replaced by ordinary functional derivatives, and the projections are dropped, then the result is a non-covariant effective action contribution Γnc(1)superscriptsubscriptΓnc1\Gamma_{\rm nc}^{(1)},

Γnc(1)=ℏ2​i​tr​ln⁡{∂I∂JS+λg​RI​α​RJ​α}−ℏi​tr​ln⁡{λg1/2​RI​α​RI​β}.superscriptsubscriptΓnc1Planck-constant-over-2-pi2𝑖trsuperscript𝐼subscript𝐽𝑆subscript𝜆𝑔superscript𝑅𝐼𝛼subscript𝑅𝐽𝛼Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝑖trsuperscriptsubscript𝜆𝑔12superscript𝑅𝐼𝛼subscript𝑅𝐼𝛽\Gamma_{\rm nc}^{(1)}={\hbar\over 2i}{\rm tr}\ln\left\{\partial^{I}\partial_{J}S+\lambda_{g}R^{I\alpha}R_{J\alpha}\right\}-{\hbar\over i}{\rm tr}\ln\left\{\lambda_{g}^{1/2}R^{I\alpha}R_{I\beta}\right\}. (18)

If the background fields are ‘on shell’, specifically when ∂IS=0subscript𝐼𝑆0\partial_{I}S=0, then the connection ∇I→∂I→subscript∇𝐼subscript𝐼\nabla_{I}\to\partial_{I}, and the covariant and non-covariant results coincide, Γ(1)=Γnc(1)superscriptΓ1superscriptsubscriptΓnc1\Gamma^{(1)}=\Gamma_{\rm nc}^{(1)}. Most calculations are done on shell, and Eq. (18) is the traditional route to evaluation of the effective action.

We will show that the off-shell result can be simplified in two equivalent ways. Firstly

Γ(1)=ℏ2​i​tr​ln⁡{Π​(𝒟I​𝒟J​S)​Π}−ℏ2​i​tr​ln⁡{RI​α​RI​β},superscriptΓ1Planck-constant-over-2-pi2𝑖trΠsuperscript𝒟𝐼subscript𝒟𝐽𝑆ΠPlanck-constant-over-2-pi2𝑖trsuperscript𝑅𝐼𝛼subscript𝑅𝐼𝛽\Gamma^{(1)}={\hbar\over 2i}{\rm tr}\ln\left\{\Pi({\cal D}^{I}{\cal D}_{J}S)\Pi\right\}-{\hbar\over 2i}{\rm tr}\ln\left\{R^{I\alpha}R_{I\beta}\right\}, (19)

where the logarithms are interpreted in a particular way described below. If we have n𝑛n fields and m𝑚m gauge variations, then there are n−m𝑛𝑚n-m non-gauge fields but there are n−2​m𝑛2𝑚n-2m degrees of freedom. The ghost contribution accounts for the difference between these two.

The second method is to use the Landau gauge λg→∞→subscript𝜆𝑔\lambda_{g}\to\infty,

Γ(1)=limλg→∞ℏ2​i​tr​ln⁡{𝒟I​𝒟J​S+λg​RI​α​RJ​α}−ℏi​tr​ln⁡{λg1/2​RI​α​RI​β},superscriptΓ1subscript→subscript𝜆𝑔Planck-constant-over-2-pi2𝑖trsuperscript𝒟𝐼subscript𝒟𝐽𝑆subscript𝜆𝑔superscript𝑅𝐼𝛼subscript𝑅𝐽𝛼Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝑖trsuperscriptsubscript𝜆𝑔12superscript𝑅𝐼𝛼subscript𝑅𝐼𝛽\Gamma^{(1)}=\lim_{\lambda_{g}\to\infty}{\hbar\over 2i}{\rm tr}\ln\left\{{\cal D}^{I}{\cal D}_{J}S+\lambda_{g}R^{I\alpha}R_{J\alpha}\right\}-{\hbar\over i}{\rm tr}\ln\left\{\lambda_{g}^{1/2}R^{I\alpha}R_{I\beta}\right\}, (20)

This appears to be more complicated, but the advantage of this method is that removing the projection operators leaves an operator which is explicitly local in spacetime, making it suitable for adiabatic expansion techniques.

For simplicity, we define the functional traces using Euclidean methods with

tr​ln⁡AL=−i​ζ′​(0,A)−i​ζ​(0,A)​ln⁡μR2,trsubscript𝐴𝐿𝑖superscript𝜁′0𝐴𝑖𝜁0𝐴superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑅2{\rm tr}\ln\,A_{L}=-i\zeta^{\prime}(0,A)-i\zeta(0,A)\ln\mu_{R}^{2}, (21)

where A𝐴A is a positive definite operator obtained from the Lorentzian operator ALsubscript𝐴𝐿A_{L} by analytic continuation of the time-like coordinate. This limits us to metrics with a valid analytic continuation. The generalised zeta-function is defined by ζ​(s,A)=tr​A−s𝜁𝑠𝐴trsuperscript𝐴𝑠\zeta(s,A)={\rm tr}A^{-s} and μRsubscript𝜇𝑅\mu_{R} is the renormalisation scale. We can read off the scaling of the Euclidean effective action ΓEsubscriptΓ𝐸\Gamma_{E} from (20)

μR​d​ΓE(1)d​μR=ℏ​limλg→∞{−ζ​(0,𝒟I​𝒟J​S+λg​RI​α​RJ​α)+2​ζ​(0,λg1/2​ℛI​α​ℛI​β)}.subscript𝜇𝑅𝑑subscriptsuperscriptΓ1𝐸𝑑subscript𝜇𝑅Planck-constant-over-2-pisubscript→subscript𝜆𝑔𝜁0superscript𝒟𝐼subscript𝒟𝐽𝑆subscript𝜆𝑔superscript𝑅𝐼𝛼subscript𝑅𝐽𝛼2𝜁0superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑔12superscriptℛ𝐼𝛼subscriptℛ𝐼𝛽\mu_{R}{d\Gamma^{(1)}_{E}\over d\mu_{R}}=\hbar\lim_{\lambda_{g}\to\infty}\left\{-\zeta\left(0,{\cal D}^{I}{\cal D}_{J}S+\lambda_{g}R^{I\alpha}R_{J\alpha}\right)+2\zeta\left(0,\lambda_{g}^{1/2}{\cal R}^{I\alpha}{\cal R}_{I\beta}\right)\right\}. (22)

In Landau gauge, the operators are local, and it is possible to prove that ζ​(0,A)𝜁0𝐴\zeta(0,A) can be expressed in terms of a local adiabatic expansion coefficient b2​(A)subscript𝑏2𝐴b_{2}(A),

ζ​(0,A)=116​π2​∫b2​(A)​|g|1/2​d4​x.𝜁0𝐴116superscript𝜋2subscript𝑏2𝐴superscript𝑔12superscript𝑑4𝑥\zeta(0,A)={1\over 16\pi^{2}}\int b_{2}(A)|g|^{1/2}d^{4}x. (23)

Eq. (22) is the origin of the renormalisation group equation (2) we gave in the introduction. For Laplace type operators A=−∇2+E𝐴superscript∇2𝐸A=-\nabla^{2}+E, the expansion coefficient b2​(A)subscript𝑏2𝐴b_{2}(A) is an invariant polynomial combination of the spacetime curvature and derivatives of E𝐸E. In Ref Moss:2013cba , it was shown that the expansion coefficients remain polynomial for some classes of non-Laplacian operators relevant to the covariant effective action. In these cases, we can use b2​(A)subscript𝑏2𝐴b_{2}(A) to read off the rescaling behaviour of the terms in the effective potential or the effective Lagrangian using the renormalisation group equation (2).

Since the scaling relations obtained from b2subscript𝑏2b_{2} are local, and the difference between covariant and non-covariant effective actions vanishes when ∂IS=0subscript𝐼𝑆0\partial_{I}S=0, we can conclude that

μR​d​Γnc(1)d​μR−μR​d​ΓE(1)d​μR=fI​∂IS,subscript𝜇𝑅𝑑subscriptsuperscriptΓ1nc𝑑subscript𝜇𝑅subscript𝜇𝑅𝑑superscriptsubscriptΓ𝐸1𝑑subscript𝜇𝑅superscript𝑓𝐼subscript𝐼𝑆\mu_{R}{d\Gamma^{(1)}_{\rm nc}\over d\mu_{R}}-\mu_{R}{d\Gamma_{E}^{(1)}\over d\mu_{R}}=f^{I}\partial_{I}S, (24)

where fIsuperscript𝑓𝐼f^{I} is a tensor polynomial expression of order ℏPlanck-constant-over-2-pi\hbar in the loop expansion. The non-covariant results are mostly known already, so this relation provides both a check on new covariant results and a possible route to finding the covariant β𝛽\beta-functions. Furthermore, we can combine the terms at one loop order into

μR​d​Γnc(1)​[φ]d​μR=μR​d​ΓE(1)​[φ+f​ln⁡μR]d​μR+O​(ℏ2).subscript𝜇𝑅𝑑subscriptsuperscriptΓ1ncdelimited-[]𝜑𝑑subscript𝜇𝑅subscript𝜇𝑅𝑑superscriptsubscriptΓ𝐸1delimited-[]𝜑𝑓subscript𝜇𝑅𝑑subscript𝜇𝑅𝑂superscriptPlanck-constant-over-2-pi2\mu_{R}{d\Gamma^{(1)}_{\rm nc}[\varphi]\over d\mu_{R}}=\mu_{R}{d\Gamma_{E}^{(1)}[\varphi+f\ln\mu_{R}]\over d\mu_{R}}+O(\hbar^{2}). (25)

Note that this does not imply that the approaches are equivalent, because the covariant action is covariant not invariant under field redefinitions. In the introduction, we described how to construct the renormalisation group corrected Lagrangian ℒ′superscriptℒ′{\cal L}^{\prime} from the rescaling behaviour of the action at one loop. Following the same procedure we see that the effective actions Γ′superscriptΓ′\Gamma^{\prime} constructed from the covariant and the non-covariant effective actions are related by a field transformation,

Γnc′​[φ]=ΓE′​[φ−f​t],subscriptsuperscriptΓ′ncdelimited-[]𝜑superscriptsubscriptΓ𝐸′delimited-[]𝜑𝑓𝑡\Gamma^{\prime}_{\rm nc}[\varphi]=\Gamma_{E}^{\prime}[\varphi-ft], (26)

where t=ln⁡(ϕ/M)𝑡italic-ϕ𝑀t=\ln(\phi/M). After expanding out again

Γnc′​[φ]=ΓE′​[φ]−t​fI​∂IΓE′​[φ]+O​(t2​ℏ2).subscriptsuperscriptΓ′ncdelimited-[]𝜑superscriptsubscriptΓ𝐸′delimited-[]𝜑𝑡superscript𝑓𝐼subscript𝐼superscriptsubscriptΓ𝐸′delimited-[]𝜑𝑂superscript𝑡2superscriptPlanck-constant-over-2-pi2\Gamma^{\prime}_{\rm nc}[\varphi]=\Gamma_{E}^{\prime}[\varphi]-tf^{I}\,\partial_{I}\Gamma_{E}^{\prime}[\varphi]+O(t^{2}\hbar^{2}). (27)

At this point, we are unsure about the size of the O​(t2​ℏ2)𝑂superscript𝑡2superscriptPlanck-constant-over-2-pi2O(t^{2}\hbar^{2}) terms. In the one loop result (25), logarithms endanger the loop expansion when the logarithms are large. We corrected for this by using the effective couplings. The new remainder term depends on the combination f​t𝑓𝑡ft. If we take the case where the remainder is small, and apply the corrected field equations ∂IΓ′=0subscript𝐼superscriptΓ′0\partial_{I}\Gamma^{\prime}=0, as we might use to calculate tunnelling amplitudes for example, then the non-covariant action has the same value as the covariant action. However, we see that for large field values the remainder term may be large, and there is a possible discrepancy between the non-covariant and covariant renormalisation group corrected potentials even when on shell.

To obtain the two representations of the covariant effective action given earlier, first split φI→(ξI,θI)→superscript𝜑𝐼superscript𝜉𝐼superscript𝜃𝐼\varphi^{I}\to(\xi^{I},\theta^{I}) into non-gauge and pure-gauge directions. Decompose the operator 𝒟I​𝒟J​Ssuperscript𝒟𝐼subscript𝒟𝐽𝑆{\cal D}^{I}{\cal D}_{J}S as

𝒟I​𝒟J​S=A=(acc†d)superscript𝒟𝐼subscript𝒟𝐽𝑆𝐴matrix𝑎𝑐superscript𝑐†𝑑{\cal D}^{I}{\cal D}_{J}S=A=\begin{pmatrix}a&c\\ c^{\dagger}&d\\ \end{pmatrix} (28)

Similarly decompose

RI​α​RJ​α=B=(000b)superscript𝑅𝐼𝛼subscript𝑅𝐽𝛼𝐵matrix000𝑏R^{I\alpha}R_{J\alpha}=B=\begin{pmatrix}0&0\\ 0&b\\ \end{pmatrix} (29)

Eq. (19) follows from this decomposition when we set λg=1subscript𝜆𝑔1\lambda_{g}=1 in the one-loop result (17). Noting that the non-zero eigenvalues of RI​α​RJ​αsuperscript𝑅𝐼𝛼subscript𝑅𝐽𝛼R^{I\alpha}R_{J\alpha} and RI​α​RI​βsuperscript𝑅𝐼𝛼subscript𝑅𝐼𝛽R^{I\alpha}R_{I\beta} are identical,

Γ(1)=ℏ2​i​tr​ln⁡a+ℏ2​i​tr​ln⁡b−ℏi​tr​ln⁡b=ℏ2​i​tr​ln⁡a−ℏ2​i​tr​ln⁡b.superscriptΓ1Planck-constant-over-2-pi2𝑖tr𝑎Planck-constant-over-2-pi2𝑖tr𝑏Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝑖tr𝑏Planck-constant-over-2-pi2𝑖tr𝑎Planck-constant-over-2-pi2𝑖tr𝑏\Gamma^{(1)}={\hbar\over 2i}{\rm tr}\ln a+{\hbar\over 2i}{\rm tr}\ln b-{\hbar\over i}{\rm tr}\ln b={\hbar\over 2i}{\rm tr}\ln a-{\hbar\over 2i}{\rm tr}\ln b. (30)

This recovers Eq. (19).

For Landau gauge Eq. (20), we start with the generalised zeta-function ζ​(s,A)𝜁𝑠𝐴\zeta(s,A). Consider

ζ​(s,A+λg​B)=1Γ​(s)​∫0∞𝑑t​ts−1​tr​(e−(A+λg​B)​t)𝜁𝑠𝐴subscript𝜆𝑔𝐵1Γ𝑠superscriptsubscript0differential-d𝑡superscript𝑡𝑠1trsuperscript𝑒𝐴subscript𝜆𝑔𝐵𝑡\zeta(s,A+\lambda_{g}B)={1\over\Gamma(s)}\int_{0}^{\infty}dt\,t^{s-1}{\rm tr}\left(e^{-(A+\lambda_{g}B)t}\right) (31)

If we rescale t𝑡t,

ζ​(s,A+λg​B)=λg−sΓ​(s)​∫0∞𝑑t​ts−1​tr​(e−(B+λg−1​A)​t)𝜁𝑠𝐴subscript𝜆𝑔𝐵superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑔𝑠Γ𝑠superscriptsubscript0differential-d𝑡superscript𝑡𝑠1trsuperscript𝑒𝐵superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑔1𝐴𝑡\zeta(s,A+\lambda_{g}B)={\lambda_{g}^{-s}\over\Gamma(s)}\int_{0}^{\infty}dt\,t^{s-1}{\rm tr}\left(e^{-(B+\lambda_{g}^{-1}A)t}\right) (32)

Separate out the diagonal and non-diagonal parts,

tr​(e−(B+λg−1​A)​t)=tr​(exp⁡[−(λg−1​a00b+λg−1​d)​t]​exp⁡[−(0λg−1​cλg−1​c†0)​t])trsuperscript𝑒𝐵superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑔1𝐴𝑡trmatrixsuperscriptsubscript𝜆𝑔1𝑎00𝑏superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑔1𝑑𝑡matrix0superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑔1𝑐superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑔1superscript𝑐†0𝑡{\rm tr}\left(e^{-(B+\lambda_{g}^{-1}A)t}\right)={\rm tr}\left(\exp\left[-\begin{pmatrix}\lambda_{g}^{-1}a&0\\ 0&b+\lambda_{g}^{-1}d\\ \end{pmatrix}t\right]\exp\left[-\begin{pmatrix}0&\lambda_{g}^{-1}c\\ \lambda_{g}^{-1}c^{\dagger}&0\\ \end{pmatrix}t\right]\right) (33)

Only the even powers of λg−1superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑔1\lambda_{g}^{-1} survive in the second exponential due to the trace. Of these, only the leading term survives in the large λgsubscript𝜆𝑔\lambda_{g} limit, and after rescaling t𝑡t back,

ζ​(s,A+λg​B)=ζ​(s,a)+λg−s​ζ​(s,b+λg−1​d)+O​(λg−s−2)𝜁𝑠𝐴subscript𝜆𝑔𝐵𝜁𝑠𝑎superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑔𝑠𝜁𝑠𝑏superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑔1𝑑𝑂superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑔𝑠2\zeta(s,A+\lambda_{g}B)=\zeta(s,a)+\lambda_{g}^{-s}\zeta(s,b+\lambda_{g}^{-1}d)+O(\lambda_{g}^{-s-2}) (34)

ζ′​(0,A+λg​B)superscript𝜁′0𝐴subscript𝜆𝑔𝐵\displaystyle\zeta^{\prime}(0,A+\lambda_{g}B) ∼similar-to\displaystyle\sim ζ′​(0,a)+ζ′​(0,b)−ζ​(0,b)​ln⁡λgsuperscript𝜁′0𝑎superscript𝜁′0𝑏𝜁0𝑏subscript𝜆𝑔\displaystyle\zeta^{\prime}(0,a)+\zeta^{\prime}(0,b)-\zeta(0,b)\ln\lambda_{g} (36)

So now the terms on the right hand side of (20) are

limλg→∞ℏ2​i​tr​ln⁡{A+λg​B}−ℏi​tr​ln⁡{λg1/2​b}=ℏ2​i​tr​ln⁡a−ℏ2​i​tr​ln⁡bsubscript→subscript𝜆𝑔Planck-constant-over-2-pi2𝑖tr𝐴subscript𝜆𝑔𝐵Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝑖trsuperscriptsubscript𝜆𝑔12𝑏Planck-constant-over-2-pi2𝑖tr𝑎Planck-constant-over-2-pi2𝑖tr𝑏\lim_{\lambda_{g}\to\infty}\frac{\hbar}{2i}{\rm tr}\ln\left\{A+\lambda_{g}B\right\}-{\hbar\over i}{\rm tr}\ln\left\{\lambda_{g}^{1/2}b\right\}=\frac{\hbar}{2i}{\rm tr}\ln a-\frac{\hbar}{2i}{\rm tr}\ln b (37)

Therefore the Landau gauge result Eq. (20) is equal to Eq. (30) which is equal to the gauge decomposition Eq. (19).

3 The Gravity-Higgs effective field theory

We take the point of view that the gravity-Higgs sector is a low energy effective field theory for the spacetime metric gμ​νsubscript𝑔𝜇𝜈g_{\mu\nu} and the Higgs doublet field ℋℋ{\cal H}, in which non-renormalisable terms are assumed to be suppressed by inverse powers of the reduced Planck mass, κ=Mp−1=(8​π​G)1/2𝜅superscriptsubscript𝑀𝑝1superscript8𝜋𝐺12\kappa=M_{p}^{-1}=(8\pi G)^{1/2} Burgess:2003jk . Since Higgs instability sets in at a scale below the Planck mass, the renormalisable couplings will be expected to play the most important role. During inflation, we suppose that the vacuum energy is dominated by an inflation field and takes some fixed value V0subscript𝑉0V_{0}, and then the expansion rate in the Higgs vacuum is determined by the Friedman equation H2=κ2​V0/3superscript𝐻2superscript𝜅2subscript𝑉03H^{2}=\kappa^{2}V_{0}/3.

For convenience, we replace the Higgs doublet by a set of four real scalars ϕisuperscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖\phi^{i}, denoting the gauge invariant magnitude of the field by ϕitalic-ϕ\phi and the projection orthogonal to ϕisuperscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖\phi^{i} by δi​j⟂subscriptsuperscript𝛿perpendicular-to𝑖𝑗\delta^{\perp}_{ij}. The Lagrangian density for the gravity-Higgs sector ℒgsubscriptℒ𝑔{\cal L}_{g} with non-minimal coupling is

ℒg​(g,ϕ)=12​κ2​U​(ϕ)​R​(g)​|g|1/2−12​Gi​j​(ϕ)​gμ​ν​∂μϕi​∂νϕj​|g|1/2−V​(ϕ)​|g|1/2,subscriptℒ𝑔𝑔italic-ϕ12superscript𝜅2𝑈italic-ϕ𝑅𝑔superscript𝑔1212subscript𝐺𝑖𝑗italic-ϕsuperscript𝑔𝜇𝜈subscript𝜇superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖subscript𝜈superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑗superscript𝑔12𝑉italic-ϕsuperscript𝑔12{\cal L}_{g}(g,\phi)={1\over 2\kappa^{2}}U(\phi)R(g)\,|g|^{1/2}-\frac{1}{2}G_{ij}(\phi)\,g^{\mu\nu}\partial_{\mu}\phi^{i}\partial_{\nu}\phi^{j}\,|g|^{1/2}-V(\phi)\,|g|^{1/2}, (38)

where ∂μsubscript𝜇\partial_{\mu} denotes an ordinary spacetime derivative. The non-minimal coupling terms are contained in the function U​(ϕ)𝑈italic-ϕU(\phi) multiplying the Ricci scalar R𝑅R.

Each one of the scalar functions in the Lagrangian has an expansion in powers of κ𝜅\kappa,

V​(ϕ)𝑉italic-ϕ\displaystyle V(\phi) =\displaystyle= V0+12​μ2​ϕ2+14​λ​ϕ4+16​λ6​κ2​ϕ6+…subscript𝑉012superscript𝜇2superscriptitalic-ϕ214𝜆superscriptitalic-ϕ416subscript𝜆6superscript𝜅2superscriptitalic-ϕ6…\displaystyle V_{0}+\frac{1}{2}\mu^{2}\phi^{2}+\frac{1}{4}\lambda\phi^{4}+\frac{1}{6}\lambda_{6}\kappa^{2}\phi^{6}+\dots (39)
Gi​j​(ϕ)subscript𝐺𝑖𝑗italic-ϕ\displaystyle G_{ij}(\phi) =\displaystyle= δi​j+α​κ2​δi​k​δj​l​ϕk​ϕl+β​κ2​δi​j⟂​ϕ2+…subscript𝛿𝑖𝑗𝛼superscript𝜅2subscript𝛿𝑖𝑘subscript𝛿𝑗𝑙superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑙𝛽superscript𝜅2subscriptsuperscript𝛿perpendicular-to𝑖𝑗superscriptitalic-ϕ2…\displaystyle\delta_{ij}+\alpha\kappa^{2}\delta_{ik}\delta_{jl}\phi^{k}\phi^{l}+\beta\kappa^{2}\delta^{\perp}_{ij}\phi^{2}+\dots (40)
U​(ϕ)𝑈italic-ϕ\displaystyle U(\phi) =\displaystyle= 1−ξ​κ2​ϕ2+…,1𝜉superscript𝜅2superscriptitalic-ϕ2…\displaystyle 1-\xi\kappa^{2}\phi^{2}+\dots, (41)

Most of the results we obtain have been truncated to O​(κ2​ϕ2)𝑂superscript𝜅2superscriptitalic-ϕ2O(\kappa^{2}\phi^{2}). We will use a wave function renormalisation to the keep the leading order behaviour in R𝑅R and Gi​jsubscript𝐺𝑖𝑗G_{ij} fixed. The anomalous dimensions will be denoted by γgsubscript𝛾𝑔\gamma_{g} and γϕsubscript𝛾italic-ϕ\gamma_{\phi} respectivly. This keeps the effective Planck scale fixed. Note that it is not possible to eliminate both coefficients α𝛼\alpha and β𝛽\beta by redefinitions of ϕitalic-ϕ\phi if Gi​jsubscript𝐺𝑖𝑗G_{ij} has a non-vanishing curvature tensor.

One of the questions we address is the effect of conformal rescaling of the metric from the original Jordan Frame to the Einstein frame to remove the ξ𝜉\xi term in the original Lagrangian. We set the metric to be gE=U​(ϕ)​gsubscript𝑔𝐸𝑈italic-ϕ𝑔g_{E}=U(\phi)g, then

ℒg​(gE,ϕ)=12​κ2​R​(gE)​|gE|1/2−12​GE​i​j​(ϕ)​gEμ​ν​∂μϕi​∂νϕj​|gE|1/2−VE​(ϕ)​|gE|1/2,subscriptℒ𝑔subscript𝑔𝐸italic-ϕ12superscript𝜅2𝑅subscript𝑔𝐸superscriptsubscript𝑔𝐸1212subscript𝐺𝐸𝑖𝑗italic-ϕsuperscriptsubscript𝑔𝐸𝜇𝜈subscript𝜇superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖subscript𝜈superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑔𝐸12subscript𝑉𝐸italic-ϕsuperscriptsubscript𝑔𝐸12{\cal L}_{g}(g_{E},\phi)={1\over 2\kappa^{2}}R(g_{E})\,|g_{E}|^{1/2}-\frac{1}{2}G_{Eij}(\phi)\,g_{E}^{\mu\nu}\partial_{\mu}\phi^{i}\partial_{\nu}\phi^{j}\,|g_{E}|^{1/2}-V_{E}(\phi)\,|g_{E}|^{1/2}, (42)

where

VE​(ϕ)subscript𝑉𝐸italic-ϕ\displaystyle V_{E}(\phi) =\displaystyle= U−2​V​(ϕ)superscript𝑈2𝑉italic-ϕ\displaystyle U^{-2}V(\phi) (43)
GE​i​j​(ϕ)subscript𝐺𝐸𝑖𝑗italic-ϕ\displaystyle G_{Eij}(\phi) =\displaystyle= U−1​Gi​j+32​κ−2​U−2​∂U∂ϕi​∂U∂ϕjsuperscript𝑈1subscript𝐺𝑖𝑗32superscript𝜅2superscript𝑈2𝑈superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑈superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑗\displaystyle U^{-1}G_{ij}+\frac{3}{2}\kappa^{-2}U^{-2}{\partial U\over\partial\phi^{i}}{\partial U\over\partial\phi^{j}} (44)

In a covariant theory it should be possible to calculate the beta functions by transforming to the Einstein frame, rescaling the effective action, and transforming back to the Jordan frame.

If we expand the Einstein frame theory in powers of κ𝜅\kappa we have relationships between the sets of Einstein frame and Jordan frame parameters,

μE2superscriptsubscript𝜇𝐸2\displaystyle\mu_{E}^{2} =\displaystyle= μ2+4​ξ′​κ2​V0superscript𝜇24superscript𝜉′superscript𝜅2subscript𝑉0\displaystyle\mu^{2}+4\xi^{\prime}\kappa^{2}V_{0} (45)
λEsubscript𝜆𝐸\displaystyle\lambda_{E} =\displaystyle= λ+4​ξ′​κ2​μ2𝜆4superscript𝜉′superscript𝜅2superscript𝜇2\displaystyle\lambda+4\xi^{\prime}\kappa^{2}\mu^{2} (46)
ξEsubscript𝜉𝐸\displaystyle\xi_{E} =\displaystyle= ξ−ξ′.𝜉superscript𝜉′\displaystyle\xi-\xi^{\prime}. (47)

Note that we have used a different ξ′superscript𝜉′\xi^{\prime} for the conformal transformation. Since we have adopted a covariant quantisation approach, these relations also hold for the running couplings up to field renormalisation factors. We differentiate the relations with respect to the renormalisation scale keeping ξ′superscript𝜉′\xi^{\prime} fixed, and then set ξ′=ξsuperscript𝜉′𝜉\xi^{\prime}=\xi at the end,

β~μ2​(0,λE,μE2,…)subscript~𝛽superscript𝜇20subscript𝜆𝐸subscriptsuperscript𝜇2𝐸…\displaystyle\tilde{\beta}_{\mu^{2}}(0,\lambda_{E},\mu^{2}_{E},\dots) =\displaystyle= β~μ2​(ξ,λ,μ2,…)+4​ξ​κ2​β~V0​(ξ,λ,μ2,…)subscript~𝛽superscript𝜇2𝜉𝜆superscript𝜇2…4𝜉superscript𝜅2subscript~𝛽subscript𝑉0𝜉𝜆superscript𝜇2…\displaystyle\tilde{\beta}_{\mu^{2}}(\xi,\lambda,\mu^{2},\dots)+4\xi\kappa^{2}\tilde{\beta}_{V_{0}}(\xi,\lambda,\mu^{2},\dots) (48)
β~λ​(0,λE,μE2,…)subscript~𝛽𝜆0subscript𝜆𝐸subscriptsuperscript𝜇2𝐸…\displaystyle\tilde{\beta}_{\lambda}(0,\lambda_{E},\mu^{2}_{E},\dots) =\displaystyle= β~λ​(ξ,λ,μ2,…)+4​ξ​κ2​β~μ2​(ξ,λ,μ2,…)subscript~𝛽𝜆𝜉𝜆superscript𝜇2…4𝜉superscript𝜅2subscript~𝛽superscript𝜇2𝜉𝜆superscript𝜇2…\displaystyle\tilde{\beta}_{\lambda}(\xi,\lambda,\mu^{2},\dots)+4\xi\kappa^{2}\tilde{\beta}_{\mu^{2}}(\xi,\lambda,\mu^{2},\dots) (49)
β~ξ​(0,λE,μE2,…)subscript~𝛽𝜉0subscript𝜆𝐸subscriptsuperscript𝜇2𝐸…\displaystyle\tilde{\beta}_{\xi}(0,\lambda_{E},\mu^{2}_{E},\dots) =\displaystyle= β~ξ​(ξ,λ,μ2,…)subscript~𝛽𝜉𝜉𝜆superscript𝜇2…\displaystyle\tilde{\beta}_{\xi}(\xi,\lambda,\mu^{2},\dots) (50)

The beta functions β~~𝛽\tilde{\beta} include anomalous dimension factors, for example

β~ξ=βξ−2​γϕ​ξ−γg​ξ.subscript~𝛽𝜉subscript𝛽𝜉2subscript𝛾italic-ϕ𝜉subscript𝛾𝑔𝜉\tilde{\beta}_{\xi}=\beta_{\xi}-2\gamma_{\phi}\xi-\gamma_{g}\xi. (51)

These relations can be used to evaluate covariant beta functions for non-zero curvature coupling if we have results for minimal coupling.

Already, an unexpected result follows from (50), namely that the one-loop βξsubscript𝛽𝜉\beta_{\xi} for gravity-Higgs theory is independent of ξ𝜉\xi at order κ0superscript𝜅0\kappa^{0}. Paradoxically, the quantum theory of scalar fields on a curved background gives βξ∝6​ξ−1proportional-tosubscript𝛽𝜉6𝜉1\beta_{\xi}\propto 6\xi-1 Buchbinder:1986yh . The ξ𝜉\xi dependence must cancel when we include quantum gravity and require field-covariance of the effective action. Subsequent results will confirm this using explicit calculations.

4 Expansions of the gravity-Higgs action

We will give results for the second order variations of the gravity-Higgs effective theory which are needed to evaluate the beta functions. Most of the details have been left out because these are already covered in the literature, particularly in the work of Barvinsky et al. Barvinsky:2009ii ; Barvinsky:2009fy ; Barvinsky:2010yb ). We use the Jordan frame formulation and then the covariant formulation can be checked by verifying the relations between the beta functions give in Eqs (48)-(50).

Variations in field space can be combined into metric and scalar directions, and we rescale these to have the same dimensions, i.e.

∂IS=(2​κ​δ​Sδ​gμ​ν,δ​Sδ​ϕi)subscript𝐼𝑆2𝜅𝛿𝑆𝛿subscript𝑔𝜇𝜈𝛿𝑆𝛿superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖\partial_{I}S=\left(2\kappa{\delta S\over\delta g_{\mu\nu}},{\delta S\over\delta\phi^{i}}\right) (52)

The second-order variation of the action gives a second order differential operator,

−𝒟I𝒟JS=−∂I∂JS+ΓK∂KI​JS=−𝒢I​J∇2−𝒫α​β∇αI​J∇β+EI​J,-{\cal D}_{I}{\cal D}_{J}S=-\partial_{I}\partial_{J}S+\Gamma^{K}{}_{IJ}\partial_{K}S=-{\cal G}_{IJ}\nabla^{2}-{\cal P}^{\alpha\beta}{}_{IJ}\nabla_{\alpha}\nabla_{\beta}+E_{IJ}, (53)

There are three important tensors in this expression which will be presented below: 𝒢I​Jsubscript𝒢𝐼𝐽{\cal G}_{IJ} is the metric on field space, 𝒫I​Jα​βsubscriptsuperscript𝒫𝛼𝛽𝐼𝐽{\cal P}^{\alpha\beta}_{IJ} projects out the gauge-fixed directions, and EI​Jsubscript𝐸𝐼𝐽E_{IJ} is an effective mass term. The metric is used to construct the Levy-Civita connection by the usual expression,

ΓI=J​K12𝒢I​L(∂K𝒢L​J+∂J𝒢L​K−∂L𝒢J​K).\Gamma^{I}{}_{JK}=\frac{1}{2}{\cal G}^{IL}\left(\partial_{K}{\cal G}_{LJ}+\partial_{J}{\cal G}_{LK}-\partial_{L}{\cal G}_{JK}\right). (54)

When writing down local operators like 𝒢I​Jsubscript𝒢𝐼𝐽{\cal G}_{IJ} we usually omit delta function terms.

4.1 First order variations

The first order variation of the action defines the background field equations for the gravitational and Higgs fields, which will be denoted by Fμ​νsuperscript𝐹𝜇𝜈F^{\mu\nu} and Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i},

Fμ​ν=−κgδ​Sδ​gμ​ν=UGμ​ν−U;μν+gμ​νU;ρ−ρκ2Tμ​ν,\displaystyle F^{\mu\nu}=-{\kappa\over\sqrt{g}}{\delta S\over\delta g_{\mu\nu}}=UG^{\mu\nu}-U^{;\mu\nu}+g^{\mu\nu}U^{;\rho}{}_{\rho}-\kappa^{2}T^{\mu\nu}, (55)
Fi=−1g​δ​Sδ​ϕi=−12​κ2​R​U,i−Dμ​(Gi​j​∇μϕi)+V,i,\displaystyle F_{i}=-{1\over\sqrt{g}}{\delta S\over\delta\phi^{i}}=-{1\over 2\kappa^{2}}RU_{,i}-D_{\mu}(G_{ij}\nabla^{\mu}\phi^{i})+V_{,i}, (56)

where Dμsubscript𝐷𝜇D_{\mu} is a covariant derivative for the metric Gi​jsubscript𝐺𝑖𝑗G_{ij},

Dμδϕi=∂μδϕi−Γi(∂μϕj)j​kδϕkD_{\mu}\delta\phi^{i}=\partial_{\mu}\delta\phi^{i}-\Gamma^{i}{}_{jk}(\partial_{\mu}\phi^{j})\delta\phi^{k} (57)

Note that Fμ​νsuperscript𝐹𝜇𝜈F^{\mu\nu} has been scaled so that Fμ​ν=0superscript𝐹𝜇𝜈0F^{\mu\nu}=0 resembles the usual Einstein equation.

4.2 Second order variations

For simplicity, the background scalar field will be assumed constant. The second order variation −∂I∂JSgsubscript𝐼subscript𝐽subscript𝑆𝑔-\partial_{I}\partial_{J}S_{g} has derivative terms

(−U​g(μ​ν)​(ρ​σ)​∇2+U​Pα​β​(μ​ν)​(ρ​σ)​∇α∇β−κ−1​U,j​(∇μ∇ν−gμ​ν​∇2)−κ−1​U,i​(∇ρ∇σ−gρ​σ​∇2)−Gi​j​∇2)​|g|1/2,\begin{pmatrix}-Ug^{(\mu\nu)(\rho\sigma)}\nabla^{2}+UP^{\alpha\beta(\mu\nu)(\rho\sigma)}\nabla_{\alpha}\nabla_{\beta}&-\kappa^{-1}U_{,j}(\nabla^{\mu}\nabla^{\nu}-g^{\mu\nu}\nabla^{2})\\ -\kappa^{-1}U_{,i}(\nabla^{\rho}\nabla^{\sigma}-g^{\rho\sigma}\nabla^{2})&-G_{ij}\nabla^{2}\\ \end{pmatrix}|g|^{1/2}, (58)

and a potential term,

Eg​I​J=(Eg(μ​ν)​(ρ​σ)κ​gμ​ν​V,jκ​gρ​σ​V,iV,ij−12​R​κ−2​U,ij)​|g|1/2,E_{g\,IJ}=\begin{pmatrix}E_{g}^{(\mu\nu)(\rho\sigma)}&\kappa g^{\mu\nu}V_{,j}\\ \kappa g^{\rho\sigma}V_{,i}&V_{,ij}-\frac{1}{2}R\kappa^{-2}U_{,ij}\\ \end{pmatrix}|g|^{1/2}, (59)

Two important tensors in the kinetic terms are the DeWitt metric,

g(μ​ν)​(ρ​σ)=12​(gμ​ρ​gν​σ+gμ​σ​gν​ρ−gμ​ν​gρ​σ),superscript𝑔𝜇𝜈𝜌𝜎12superscript𝑔𝜇𝜌superscript𝑔𝜈𝜎superscript𝑔𝜇𝜎superscript𝑔𝜈𝜌superscript𝑔𝜇𝜈superscript𝑔𝜌𝜎g^{(\mu\nu)(\rho\sigma)}=\frac{1}{2}(g^{\mu\rho}g^{\nu\sigma}+g^{\mu\sigma}g^{\nu\rho}-g^{\mu\nu}g^{\rho\sigma}), (60)

and another tensor which will also appear in the gauge-fixing terms below,

Pα​β​(μ​ν)​(ρ​σ)=2​gγ​δ​g(α​γ)​(μ​ν)​g(β​δ)​(ρ​σ).superscript𝑃𝛼𝛽𝜇𝜈𝜌𝜎2subscript𝑔𝛾𝛿superscript𝑔𝛼𝛾𝜇𝜈superscript𝑔𝛽𝛿𝜌𝜎P^{\alpha\beta(\mu\nu)(\rho\sigma)}=2g_{\gamma\delta}g^{(\alpha\gamma)(\mu\nu)}g^{(\beta\delta)(\rho\sigma)}. (61)

The mass-like gravity terms are

Eg(μ​ν)​(ρ​σ)=−2​U​Rμ˙​ρ​ν˙​σ+2​U​Rμ˙​ρ​gν˙​σ+U​RTμ​ν​gρ​σ+U​gμ​ν​RTρ​σ−4​U​RTμ˙​ρ​gν˙​σ−2​κ2​V​g(μ​ν)​(ρ​σ).superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑔𝜇𝜈𝜌𝜎2𝑈superscript𝑅˙𝜇𝜌˙𝜈𝜎2𝑈superscript𝑅˙𝜇𝜌superscript𝑔˙𝜈𝜎𝑈superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑇𝜇𝜈superscript𝑔𝜌𝜎𝑈superscript𝑔𝜇𝜈superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑇𝜌𝜎4𝑈superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑇˙𝜇𝜌superscript𝑔˙𝜈𝜎2superscript𝜅2𝑉superscript𝑔𝜇𝜈𝜌𝜎E_{g}^{(\mu\nu)(\rho\sigma)}=-2UR^{\dot{\mu}\rho\dot{\nu}\sigma}+2UR^{\dot{\mu}\rho}g^{\dot{\nu}\sigma}+UR_{T}^{\mu\nu}g^{\rho\sigma}+Ug^{\mu\nu}R_{T}^{\rho\sigma}-4UR_{T}^{\dot{\mu}\rho}g^{\dot{\nu}\sigma}-2\kappa^{2}Vg^{(\mu\nu)(\rho\sigma)}. (62)

Dots over indices indicate symmetrisation in those indices and a subscript T𝑇T denotes the trace-free part of the tensor. The terms have been organised this way to isolate terms which vanish when the differential operator is applied to transverse traceless perturbations and terms which remain.

Gauge-fixing terms have to be included in the action, and following Barvinski Barvinsky:2009ii we take

ℒgf=−λg​U​gμ​ν​χμ​χν,subscriptℒgfsubscript𝜆𝑔𝑈subscript𝑔𝜇𝜈superscript𝜒𝜇superscript𝜒𝜈{\cal L}_{\rm gf}=-\lambda_{g}Ug_{\mu\nu}\chi^{\mu}\chi^{\nu}, (63)

where

χμ=12​κ​(g(μ​ν)​(ρ​σ)​∇νδ​gρ​σ−U−1​U,i​∇μδ​ϕi)\chi^{\mu}={1\over 2\kappa}(g^{(\mu\nu)(\rho\sigma)}\nabla_{\nu}\delta g_{\rho\sigma}-U^{-1}U_{,i}\nabla^{\mu}\delta\phi^{i}) (64)

The gauge-fixing term gives a contribution to the second-order variation of,

−∂I∂JSg​f=−λg​(U​Pα​β​(μ​ν)​(ρ​σ)​∇α∇β−κ−1​U,j​g(μ​ν)​(α​β)​∇α∇β−κ−1​U,i​g(ρ​σ)​(α​β)​∇α∇β12​κ−2​U−1​U,i​U,j​∇2)​|g|1/2,-\partial_{I}\partial_{J}S_{gf}=-\lambda_{g}\begin{pmatrix}UP^{\alpha\beta(\mu\nu)(\rho\sigma)}\nabla_{\alpha}\nabla_{\beta}&-\kappa^{-1}U_{,j}g^{(\mu\nu)(\alpha\beta)}\nabla_{\alpha}\nabla_{\beta}\\ -\kappa^{-1}U_{,i}g^{(\rho\sigma)(\alpha\beta)}\nabla_{\alpha}\nabla_{\beta}&\frac{1}{2}\kappa^{-2}U^{-1}U_{,i}U_{,j}\nabla^{2}\\ \end{pmatrix}|g|^{1/2}, (65)

We have enough information now to obtain the field-space metric 𝒢I​Jsubscript𝒢𝐼𝐽{\cal G}_{IJ}. We will do this by requiring the operator to have Laplacian form in the gauge-fixed directions, i.e.

−(∂I∂JSg)​δ​φI=−𝒢I​J​∇2δ​φJ+EI​J​δ​φJsubscript𝐼subscript𝐽subscript𝑆𝑔𝛿superscript𝜑𝐼subscript𝒢𝐼𝐽superscript∇2𝛿superscript𝜑𝐽subscript𝐸𝐼𝐽𝛿superscript𝜑𝐽-(\partial_{I}\partial_{J}S_{g})\delta\varphi^{I}=-{\cal G}_{IJ}\nabla^{2}\delta\varphi^{J}+E_{IJ}\delta\varphi^{J} (66)

when χμ​(δ​φ)=0superscript𝜒𝜇𝛿𝜑0\chi^{\mu}(\delta\varphi)=0. Note that variations of the gauge-fixing term vanish when applied to the gauge-fixed directions, and so an arbitrary amount of ∂I∂JSg​fsubscript𝐼subscript𝐽subscript𝑆𝑔𝑓\partial_{I}\partial_{J}S_{gf} can be added to the differential operator. However, (∂I∂JSg)+λg−1​(∂I∂JSg​f)subscript𝐼subscript𝐽subscript𝑆𝑔superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑔1subscript𝐼subscript𝐽subscript𝑆𝑔𝑓(\partial_{I}\partial_{J}S_{g})+\lambda_{g}^{-1}(\partial_{I}\partial_{J}S_{gf}) is the unique combination of the second order variations that has Laplacian form. The coefficient of −∇2superscript∇2-\nabla^{2} in this combination is therefore the field-space metric, and this gives

𝒢I​J=(U​g(μ​ν)​(ρ​σ)−12​κ−1​U,j​gμ​ν−12​κ−1​U,i​gρ​σGi​j+12​κ−2​U−1​U,i​U,j)​|g|1/2.{\cal G}_{IJ}=\begin{pmatrix}Ug^{(\mu\nu)(\rho\sigma)}&-\frac{1}{2}\kappa^{-1}U_{,j}g^{\mu\nu}\\ -\frac{1}{2}\kappa^{-1}U_{,i}g^{\rho\sigma}&G_{ij}+\frac{1}{2}\kappa^{-2}U^{-1}U_{,i}U_{,j}\\ \end{pmatrix}|g|^{1/2}. (67)

(We also obtain exactly the same result using ∂Iχα=λg1/2RIα\partial_{I}\chi^{\alpha}=\lambda_{g}^{1/2}R_{I}{}^{\alpha} for the Rξsubscript𝑅𝜉R_{\xi} gauges as in Sect. 2. This is a special feature of the gauge fixing term (64), and for other choices it becomes necessary to combine information from both gauge-fixed and pure gauge directions to obtain the metric). For future reference, the inverse metric is given by

𝒢I​J=(U−1​g(μ​ν)​(ρ​σ)+14​κ−2​U−1​U,k​U,k​W−1​gμ​ν​gρ​σ−12​κ−1​W−1​U,j​gμ​ν−12​κ−1​W−1​U,i​gρ​σGi​j−32​W−1​κ−2​U,i​U,j)​|g|−1/2.{\cal G}^{IJ}=\begin{pmatrix}U^{-1}g_{(\mu\nu)(\rho\sigma)}+\frac{1}{4}\kappa^{-2}U^{-1}U_{,k}U^{,k}W^{-1}g_{\mu\nu}g_{\rho\sigma}&-\frac{1}{2}\kappa^{-1}W^{-1}U^{,j}g_{\mu\nu}\\ -\frac{1}{2}\kappa^{-1}W^{-1}U^{,i}g_{\rho\sigma}&G^{ij}-\frac{3}{2}W^{-1}\kappa^{-2}U^{,i}U^{,j}\\ \end{pmatrix}|g|^{-1/2}. (68)

where W=U+32​κ−2​U−1​U,i​U,iW=U+\frac{3}{2}\kappa^{-2}U^{-1}U_{,i}U^{,i}.

Finally, comparing to the expression (53), we can also read off the tensor 𝒫α​βI​J{\cal P}^{\alpha\beta}{}_{IJ},

𝒫α​β=I​J(U​Pα​β​(μ​ν)​(ρ​σ)−κ−1​U,j​g(μ​ν)​(α​β)−κ−1​U,i​g(ρ​σ)​(α​β)12​κ−2​U−1​U,i​U,j)|g|1/2.{\cal P}^{\alpha\beta}{}_{IJ}=\begin{pmatrix}UP^{\alpha\beta(\mu\nu)(\rho\sigma)}&-\kappa^{-1}U_{,j}g^{(\mu\nu)(\alpha\beta)}\\ -\kappa^{-1}U_{,i}g^{(\rho\sigma)(\alpha\beta)}&\frac{1}{2}\kappa^{-2}U^{-1}U_{,i}U_{,j}\\ \end{pmatrix}|g|^{1/2}. (69)

The variations are considerably simpler in the Einstein frame U≡1𝑈1U\equiv 1. Indeed, one of the motivations for considering covariant approaches is to ensure that the Einstein frame result can always be used reliably. However, just this once, we are going to verify that the covariant result is independent of the choice of conformal frame.

4.3 Vilkovisky-DeWitt corrections

The Levy-Civita connection is given by the usual expression (54). The connection converts the scalar derivatives V,ijV_{,ij} into covariant derivatives V;ijV_{;ij}, and adds extra terms to the differential operator (53). For simplicity, we just quote the contributions up to O​(κ2)𝑂superscript𝜅2O(\kappa^{2}), and take the spacetime curvature to be of order κ2superscript𝜅2\kappa^{2} and the scalar derivatives V,iV_{,i} of order κ𝜅\kappa, then

ΓK​∂KI​J⁡Sg=(EΓ(μ​ν)​(μ​ν)−14​κ​(2​V,j−κ−2​R​U,j)​gμ​ν−14​κ​(2​V,i−κ−2​R​U,i)​gρ​σ12​(Gi​j+κ−2​U;ij)​(R−4​κ2​V)),\Gamma^{K}{}_{IJ}\partial_{K}S_{g}=\begin{pmatrix}E_{\Gamma}{}^{(\mu\nu)(\mu\nu)}&-\frac{1}{4}\kappa(2V_{,j}-\kappa^{-2}RU_{,j})g^{\mu\nu}\\ -\frac{1}{4}\kappa(2V_{,i}-\kappa^{-2}RU_{,i})g^{\rho\sigma}&\frac{1}{2}(G_{ij}+\kappa^{-2}U_{;ij})(R-4\kappa^{2}V)\\ \end{pmatrix}, (70)

where

EΓ=(μ​ν)​(ρ​σ)2Ugμ˙​ρRTν˙​σ−12URTμ​νgρ​σ−12Ugρ​σRTμ​ν.E_{\Gamma}{}^{(\mu\nu)(\rho\sigma)}=2Ug^{\dot{\mu}\rho}R_{T}^{\dot{\nu}\sigma}-\frac{1}{2}UR_{T}^{\mu\nu}g^{\rho\sigma}-\frac{1}{2}Ug^{\rho\sigma}R_{T}^{\mu\nu}. (71)

Eq. (70) is exact when in the minimally coupled case U=1𝑈1U=1. In the non-minimally coupled case, when the Levy-Civita connection term is combined with the mass terms from the second variation of the action (59), we see that the curvature coupling terms U;ij​RU_{;ij}R cancel. In particular, the 2​ξ​κ2​R2𝜉superscript𝜅2𝑅2\xi\kappa^{2}R term which would contribute ξ𝜉\xi dependence to the beta-function βξsubscript𝛽𝜉\beta_{\xi} has been cancelled off by the Vilkovisky-DeWitt corrections.

5 Gravity-Higgs mode expansions

We argued in Sect 2 that the scaling behaviour of the gravity-scalar effective action can be expressed in terms of spacetime invariant tensor combinations. General expressions for these combinations are known from heat kernel methods for a wide range of second order operators Vassilevich:2003xt ; Moss:2013cba , but there are some non-Laplace type operators where the general results are not yet available. Furthermore, it can be very cumbersome applying these general results. A more practical approach is to use a direct evaluation of the the generalised zeta function on a simple manifold for a simple operator, for example gravity with a single scalar field on the sphere Dowker:1993ww ; Cognola:2005de , and read off the relevant coefficients.

On the sphere S4subscript𝑆4S_{4}, the curvature is given in terms of the Ricci scalar

Rμ​ν​ρ​σ=112​R​(gμ​ρ​gν​σ−gμ​σ​gν​ρ),subscript𝑅𝜇𝜈𝜌𝜎112𝑅subscript𝑔𝜇𝜌subscript𝑔𝜈𝜎subscript𝑔𝜇𝜎subscript𝑔𝜈𝜌R_{\mu\nu\rho\sigma}=\frac{1}{12}R\left(g_{\mu\rho}g_{\nu\sigma}-g_{\mu\sigma}g_{\nu\rho}\right), (72)

and the radius of the sphere is 12/R12𝑅\sqrt{12/R}. Consider a single constant scalar field ϕitalic-ϕ\phi with Euclidean Lagrangian

ℒE=12​K​(ϕ)​(∇ϕ)2+V​(ϕ)−1κ2​U​(ϕ)​Rsubscriptℒ𝐸12𝐾italic-ϕsuperscript∇italic-ϕ2𝑉italic-ϕ1superscript𝜅2𝑈italic-ϕ𝑅{\cal L}_{E}=\frac{1}{2}K(\phi)(\nabla\phi)^{2}+V(\phi)-{1\over\kappa^{2}}U(\phi)R (73)

The second order operator for the Euclidean theory is

𝒟I𝒟JSE=−δI∇2J+(λg−1)ℛI​αℛJ​α+EI,J{\cal D}^{I}{\cal D}_{J}S_{E}=-\delta^{I}{}_{J}\nabla^{2}+(\lambda_{g}-1){\cal R}^{I\alpha}{\cal R}_{J\alpha}+E^{I}{}_{J}, (74)

where the general expressions for ℛI​α​ℛJ​αsuperscriptℛ𝐼𝛼subscriptℛ𝐽𝛼{\cal R}^{I\alpha}{\cal R}_{J\alpha} and EIJE^{I}{}_{J} where given in Sect. 4. For a single field, we replace V,iV_{,i} by V′superscript𝑉′V^{\prime} and V;ijV_{;ij} by the covariant derivative with metric K​(ϕ)𝐾italic-ϕK(\phi),

V′′=K1/2​(K−1/2​V′)′.superscript𝑉′′superscript𝐾12superscriptsuperscript𝐾12superscript𝑉′′V^{\prime\prime}=K^{1/2}(K^{-1/2}V^{\prime})^{\prime}. (75)

The differential operators can be diagonalised by expanding the fields in a basis of S4subscript𝑆4S_{4} orthonormal harmonics: scalar modes hSsuperscriptℎ𝑆h^{S}, transverse vector modes hVμh^{V}{}_{\mu} and transverse-traceless tensor modes hTμ​νh^{T}{}_{\mu\nu}. Transverse modes are divergence free, i.e. ∇μhV=μ0\nabla^{\mu}h^{V}{}_{\mu}=0. The eigenvalues of −∇2superscript∇2-\nabla^{2} for the respective modes are λSsubscript𝜆𝑆\lambda_{S}, λVsubscript𝜆𝑉\lambda_{V} and λTsubscript𝜆𝑇\lambda_{T}. Modes can be traded up into higher rank tensors by applying derivatives to the basic set of harmonics. The general decomposition of the metric plus scalar field into the basis of harmonic functions and their derivatives is given by mode sums with coefficients xIsuperscript𝑥𝐼x^{I},

δgμ​ν=2κ∑modes{x1hμ​νT+2x2∇(μhV+ν)x3∇μ​νhS+x4gμ​νhS},δϕi=∑modesx5hS,\delta g_{\mu\nu}=2\kappa\sum_{\rm modes}\,\left\{x^{1}h^{T}_{\mu\nu}+2x^{2}\nabla_{(\mu}h^{V}{}_{\nu)}+x^{3}\nabla_{\mu\nu}h^{S}+x^{4}g_{\mu\nu}h^{S}\right\},\qquad\delta\phi^{i}=\sum_{\rm modes}\,x^{5}h^{S}, (76)

where ∇μ​ν=∇μ∇ν−14​gμ​ν​∇2subscript∇𝜇𝜈subscript∇𝜇subscript∇𝜈14subscript𝑔𝜇𝜈superscript∇2\nabla_{\mu\nu}=\nabla_{\mu}\nabla_{\nu}-\frac{1}{4}g_{\mu\nu}\nabla^{2}. In the ghost sector, there is a similar decomposition,

cμ=∑modes{y1hV+μy2∇μhS}.c_{\mu}=\sum_{\rm modes}\,\left\{y^{1}h^{V}{}_{\mu}+y^{2}\nabla_{\mu}h^{S}\right\}. (77)

The eigenvalues of the derived modes change due to non-commutation of the covariant derivatives, for example

−∇2(∇(μhV)ν)=(λV−512R)∇(μhVν)-\nabla^{2}\left(\nabla_{(\mu}h^{V}{}_{\nu)}\right)=\left(\lambda_{V}-{\textstyle\frac{5}{12}}R\right)\nabla_{(\mu}h^{V}{}_{\nu)} (78)

The derived modes are not normalised, but their normalisation can be deduced from the original harmonic, for example

4∫∇(μhV∇(μν)hVν)|g|1/2d4x=2(λV−14R).4\int\nabla_{(\mu}h^{V}{}_{\nu)}\nabla^{(\mu}h^{V\,\nu)}|g|^{1/2}d^{4}x=2\left(\lambda_{V}-{\textstyle\frac{1}{4}}R\right). (79)

The action of the operators and products in the harmonic basis for a given set of eigenvalues can be represented now by 5×5555\times 5 matrices, which are given in appendix A.

At this point, we would like to stress an important point that the matrices 𝒟I​𝒟J​SEsubscript𝒟𝐼subscript𝒟𝐽subscript𝑆𝐸{\cal D}_{I}{\cal D}_{J}S_{E} are not positive definite, so there are directions which decrease the Euclidean action and invalidate the path integral approach. This is the famous conformal mode problem of Euclidean quantum gravity. However, the matrices representing Π​𝒟I​𝒟J​SE​ΠΠsubscript𝒟𝐼subscript𝒟𝐽subscript𝑆𝐸Π\Pi{\cal D}_{I}{\cal D}_{J}S_{E}\Pi, and 𝒟I​𝒟J​SE+λg​RI​RJ​ααsubscript𝒟𝐼subscript𝒟𝐽subscript𝑆𝐸subscript𝜆𝑔subscript𝑅𝐼superscriptsubscript𝑅𝐽𝛼𝛼{\cal D}_{I}{\cal D}_{J}S_{E}+\lambda_{g}R_{I}{}^{\alpha}R_{J\alpha} for sufficiently large λgsubscript𝜆𝑔\lambda_{g}, are both positive definite and the path integral can be defined. This is the solution to the conformal mode problem of Euclidean quantum gravity referred to in Ref. Moss:2013cba .

The renormalisation scale dependence of the one-loop effective action can be calculated in two different ways, and the comparison gives a check on the accuracy of the result. The first way is by gauge decomposition,

μR​d​ΓE(1)d​μR=−ζ​(0,Π​(𝒟I​𝒟J​S)​Π)+ζ​(0,ℛI​α​ℛI​β)subscript𝜇𝑅𝑑subscriptsuperscriptΓ1𝐸𝑑subscript𝜇𝑅𝜁0Πsuperscript𝒟𝐼subscript𝒟𝐽𝑆Π𝜁0superscriptℛ𝐼𝛼subscriptℛ𝐼𝛽\mu_{R}{d\Gamma^{(1)}_{E}\over d\mu_{R}}=-\zeta\left(0,\Pi({\cal D}^{I}{\cal D}_{J}S)\Pi\right)+\zeta\left(0,{\cal R}^{I\alpha}{\cal R}_{I\beta}\right) (80)

The second version is Landau gauge,

μR​d​ΓE(1)d​μR=limλg→∞{−ζ​(0,𝒟I​𝒟J​S+λg​RI​α​RJ​α)+2​ζ​(0,λg1/2​ℛI​α​ℛI​β)}subscript𝜇𝑅𝑑subscriptsuperscriptΓ1𝐸𝑑subscript𝜇𝑅subscript→subscript𝜆𝑔𝜁0superscript𝒟𝐼subscript𝒟𝐽𝑆subscript𝜆𝑔superscript𝑅𝐼𝛼subscript𝑅𝐽𝛼2𝜁0superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑔12superscriptℛ𝐼𝛼subscriptℛ𝐼𝛽\mu_{R}{d\Gamma^{(1)}_{E}\over d\mu_{R}}=\lim_{\lambda_{g}\to\infty}\left\{-\zeta\left(0,{\cal D}^{I}{\cal D}_{J}S+\lambda_{g}R^{I\alpha}R_{J\alpha}\right)+2\zeta\left(0,\lambda_{g}^{1/2}{\cal R}^{I\alpha}{\cal R}_{I\beta}\right)\right\} (81)

In each case, the eigenvalues are evaluated by diagonalising the matrices and the generalised zeta functions are defined for s>2𝑠2s>2 by series,

ζ​(s,A)=∑λλ−s.𝜁𝑠𝐴subscript𝜆superscript𝜆𝑠\zeta(s,A)=\sum_{\lambda}\lambda^{-s}. (82)

Spherical harmonic eigenvalues are all quadratic polynomials in a single ‘angular momentum’ index n𝑛n. After diagonalisation, the eigenvalues are algebraic functions of the spherical harmonic eigenvalues, but standard zeta-function methods can be modified to analytically continue and evaluate ζ​(0,A)𝜁0𝐴\zeta(0,A) Elizalde:1994gf .

For example, in the transverse-traceless tensor sector I=J=1𝐼𝐽1I=J=1, the eigenvalues are the same for either method,

λ=λT+U−1​mT2.𝜆subscript𝜆𝑇superscript𝑈1superscriptsubscript𝑚𝑇2\lambda=\lambda_{T}+U^{-1}m_{T}^{2}. (83)

The tensor eigenvalues are given in appendix B, and after analytic continuation using (135),

ζ(0,(𝒟2S)1)1=−118+20mT2U​R+60mT4U2​R2\zeta(0,({\cal D}^{2}S)^{1}{}_{1})=-\frac{1}{18}+20{m_{T}^{2}\over UR}+60{m_{T}^{4}\over U^{2}R^{2}} (84)

Contributions to the beta-functions from the transverse-traceless tensors can be obtained from

μR​d​ℒE(1)d​μR=−b216​π2,subscript𝜇𝑅𝑑superscriptsubscriptℒ𝐸1𝑑subscript𝜇𝑅subscript𝑏216superscript𝜋2\mu_{R}{d{\cal L}_{E}^{(1)}\over d\mu_{R}}=-{b_{2}\over 16\pi^{2}}, (85)

where the adiabatic expansion coefficient b2subscript𝑏2b_{2} can be extracted from

b2=16​π2Volume​S4ζ(0,(𝒟2S)1)1=R224ζ(0,(𝒟2S)1)1,b_{2}={16\pi^{2}\over{\rm Volume}\,S_{4}}\,\zeta(0,({\cal D}^{2}S)^{1}{}_{1})={R^{2}\over 24}\,\zeta(0,({\cal D}^{2}S)^{1}{}_{1}), (86)

b2=719432​R2−253​κ2​R​VU+10​κ4​V2U2.subscript𝑏2719432superscript𝑅2253superscript𝜅2𝑅𝑉𝑈10superscript𝜅4superscript𝑉2superscript𝑈2b_{2}={719\over 432}R^{2}-{25\over 3}{\kappa^{2}RV\over U}+10{\kappa^{4}V^{2}\over U^{2}}. (87)
