βξ−2​γϕ​ξ−γg​ξ=2​coeff​(b2,R​ϕ2)=503​κ4​V0+O​(κ6).subscript𝛽𝜉2subscript𝛾italic-ϕ𝜉subscript𝛾𝑔𝜉2coeffsubscript𝑏2𝑅superscriptitalic-ϕ2503superscript𝜅4subscript𝑉0𝑂superscript𝜅6\beta_{\xi}-2\gamma_{\phi}\xi-\gamma_{g}\xi=2\,{\rm coeff}(b_{2},R\phi^{2})={50\over 3}\kappa^{4}V_{0}+O(\kappa^{6}). (88)

Other contributions to the beta functions can be obtained in a similar way from the matrices given above, but the details are lengthy and unilluminating. The results given below have been obtained using MAPLE and most of them have been checked by hand. We will give results for the contributions to the beta functions from the Higgs background direction and the gravitational sector with which it mixes. Other contributions from the Higgs components perpendicular to the background direction (‘Goldstone-like modes’) will be given in a later section.

Tables 1 and 2 show results at leading order for small κ4​V0superscript𝜅4subscript𝑉0\kappa^{4}V_{0}, assuming that the curvature R𝑅R and the mass square μ2superscript𝜇2\mu^{2} are of order κ2​V0superscript𝜅2subscript𝑉0\kappa^{2}V_{0}. These choices are consistent when the application is to Higgs stability, where the curvature of the universe R≈4​κ2​V0𝑅4superscript𝜅2subscript𝑉0R\approx 4\kappa^{2}V_{0} and the Higgs mass is negligible. Contributions to the beta functions from the gravitational perturbations, like the transverse traceless tensor modes discussed above, enter only at order κ4​V0superscript𝜅4subscript𝑉0\kappa^{4}V_{0}, in agreement with the conclusion of Ref. Markkanen:2017dlc . However, quantum gravity does has an effect at leading order through the Vilkovisky-DeWitt connection terms in the operators.

The first thing to notice in table 1 is the absence of ξ𝜉\xi terms for βξsubscript𝛽𝜉\beta_{\xi} in the Einstein frame and the covariant results. The reason for this in the Einstein frame is obvious, since the ξ​R​ϕ2𝜉𝑅superscriptitalic-ϕ2\xi R\phi^{2} term has been eliminated by the conformal transformation, and ξ𝜉\xi appears in the Einstein frame scalar potential VJ/U2subscript𝑉𝐽superscript𝑈2V_{J}/U^{2} instead. The absence of ξ𝜉\xi in the covariant results follows from the beta-function relations (48-50). In the explicit calculation, the leading order contribution to βξsubscript𝛽𝜉\beta_{\xi} from R​U′′𝑅superscript𝑈′′RU^{\prime\prime} in the mass matrix (114) cancels with the Vilkovisky-DeWitt correction.

In table 1 we see that the renormalisation group flow of μ2+4​κ2​V0​ξsuperscript𝜇24superscript𝜅2subscript𝑉0𝜉\mu^{2}+4\kappa^{2}V_{0}\xi is the same in all the different approaches. For Higgs stability, R≈4​κ2​V0𝑅4superscript𝜅2subscript𝑉0R\approx 4\kappa^{2}V_{0}, and the effective square mass of the Higgs field μ2+ξ​R≈μ2+4​κ2​V0​ξsuperscript𝜇2𝜉𝑅superscript𝜇24superscript𝜅2subscript𝑉0𝜉\mu^{2}+\xi R\approx\mu^{2}+4\kappa^{2}V_{0}\xi. This is the crucial combination which determines whether the Higgs can survive in the false vacuum during early universe inflation, as we shall see later in Sect. 7. The non-covariant formulation in the Jordan or the Einstein frame therefore gives the same outcome for stability as the covariant approach, at least for small values of κ4​V0superscript𝜅4subscript𝑉0\kappa^{4}V_{0}.

6 Gauge bosons, Goldstone modes and fermions

We turn now to gauge bosons, Goldstone modes and fermion contributions to the effective action for the scalar field on a curved spacetime background. In this case, there are no background gauge fields and the gauge modes decouple from the graviton and scalar modes of the previous section. Quantum gravity still has an effect via the Vilkovisky-DeWitt connection term. We will describe the calculation in the Einstein frame, using the beta-function relations (48-50) to extend the results to the Jordan frame. All the results have been checked using a direct Jordan frame calculation.

The gauge-Goldstone mode action which we use is

ℒg=−14​Fa​μ​ν​Fa​μ​ν​|g|1/2−12​δi​j⟂​(Dμ​ϕ)i​(Dμ​ϕ)j​|g|1/2−V​(ϕ)​|g|1/2,subscriptℒ𝑔14subscript𝐹𝑎𝜇𝜈superscript𝐹𝑎𝜇𝜈superscript𝑔1212subscriptsuperscript𝛿perpendicular-to𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝐷𝜇italic-ϕ𝑖superscriptsuperscript𝐷𝜇italic-ϕ𝑗superscript𝑔12𝑉italic-ϕsuperscript𝑔12{\cal L}_{g}=-\frac{1}{4}F_{a\mu\nu}F^{a\mu\nu}|g|^{1/2}-\frac{1}{2}\delta^{\perp}_{ij}(D_{\mu}\phi)^{i}(D^{\mu}\phi)^{j}|g|^{1/2}-V(\phi)|g|^{1/2}, (89)

where Dμ​ϕ=∇μϕ−g​Aa​μ​Ta​ϕsubscript𝐷𝜇italic-ϕsubscript∇𝜇italic-ϕ𝑔subscript𝐴𝑎𝜇superscript𝑇𝑎italic-ϕD_{\mu}\phi=\nabla_{\mu}\phi-gA_{a\mu}T^{a}\phi and δi​j⟂subscriptsuperscript𝛿perpendicular-to𝑖𝑗\delta^{\perp}_{ij} is orthogonal to the background Higgs direction used in the previous section.

For the Electroweak theory in particular, variations in the W𝑊W, Z𝑍Z and the photon directions decouple. In one of the two ‘W𝑊W’ directions for example, φI=(AW​μ,ϕW)superscript𝜑𝐼subscript𝐴𝑊𝜇superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑊\varphi^{I}=(A_{W\mu},\phi^{W}) and the second variation of the action with respect to the field variables is

−∂I∂JSg=(−gμ​ν​∇2+∇μ∇ν+Rμ​ν+mW2−mW​∇μmW​∇ν−∇2+μ2+λ​ϕ2)​|g|1/2,subscript𝐼subscript𝐽subscript𝑆𝑔matrixsuperscript𝑔𝜇𝜈superscript∇2superscript∇𝜇superscript∇𝜈superscript𝑅𝜇𝜈superscriptsubscript𝑚𝑊2subscript𝑚𝑊superscript∇𝜇subscript𝑚𝑊superscript∇𝜈superscript∇2superscript𝜇2𝜆superscriptitalic-ϕ2superscript𝑔12-\partial_{I}\partial_{J}S_{g}=\begin{pmatrix}-g^{\mu\nu}\nabla^{2}+\nabla^{\mu}\nabla^{\nu}+R^{\mu\nu}+m_{W}^{2}&-m_{W}\nabla^{\mu}\\ m_{W}\nabla^{\nu}&-\nabla^{2}+\mu^{2}+\lambda\phi^{2}\\ \end{pmatrix}|g|^{1/2}, (90)

where mW=g​ϕ/2subscript𝑚𝑊𝑔italic-ϕ2m_{W}=g\phi/2. The second variation in the Z𝑍Z direction is similar, with mZ=(g2+g′⁣2)1/2​ϕ/2subscript𝑚𝑍superscriptsuperscript𝑔2superscript𝑔′212italic-ϕ2m_{Z}=(g^{2}+g^{\prime 2})^{1/2}\phi/2, where g′superscript𝑔′g^{\prime} is the coupling to the U​(1)𝑈1U(1) gauge field. The name ‘Goldstone modes’ has been used, although the modes are in fact massive because the background scalar field is not at the minimum of the potential.

We can read off the local field-space metric from the coefficients of the Laplacian terms, 𝒢I​J=diag​(gμ​ν,1)​|g|1/2subscript𝒢𝐼𝐽diagsuperscript𝑔𝜇𝜈1superscript𝑔12{\cal G}_{IJ}={\rm diag}(g^{\mu\nu},1)|g|^{1/2}. The Rξsubscript𝑅𝜉R_{\xi} gauges from section 2 correspond to the gauge-fixing functional

χα=∇μAa​μ−g​ϕT​Ta​δ​ϕ.superscript𝜒𝛼superscript∇𝜇subscript𝐴𝑎𝜇𝑔superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑇subscript𝑇𝑎𝛿italic-ϕ\chi^{\alpha}=\nabla^{\mu}A_{a\mu}-g\phi^{T}T_{a}\delta\phi. (91)

The gauge-fixing contribution to the action is then

RI​αRJ=α(δa​b​∇μ∇νmW​∇μ−mW​∇νmW2)|g|1/2.R_{I\alpha}R_{J}{}^{\alpha}=\begin{pmatrix}\delta^{ab}\nabla^{\mu}\nabla^{\nu}&m_{W}\nabla^{\mu}\\ -m_{W}\nabla^{\nu}&m_{W}^{2}\\ \end{pmatrix}|g|^{1/2}. (92)

The ghost operator in the gauge direction associated with the W𝑊W is

Qα=β−∇2+mW2.Q^{\alpha}{}_{\beta}=-\nabla^{2}+m_{W}^{2}. (93)

There are two ghosts associated with the W𝑊W direction and one with the Z𝑍Z direction.

In the covariant approach, there are connection terms in the differential operator 𝒟I​𝒟J​Ssubscript𝒟𝐼subscript𝒟𝐽𝑆{\cal D}_{I}{\cal D}_{J}S because the field-space metric 𝒢I​Jsubscript𝒢𝐼𝐽{\cal G}_{IJ} depends on the spacetime metric, leading to a connection coefficient ΓKI​J\Gamma^{K}{}_{IJ} with K𝐾K in the metric direction. The contribution to the operator is EΓ​I​J=ΓK​∂KI​J⁡Ssubscript𝐸Γ𝐼𝐽superscriptΓ𝐾subscriptsubscript𝐾𝐼𝐽𝑆E_{\Gamma\,IJ}=\Gamma^{K}{}_{IJ}\partial_{K}S,

EΓ​I​J=(−Gμ​ν−κ2​V​gμ​ν0012​(R−4​κ2​V))​|g|1/2,subscript𝐸Γ𝐼𝐽matrixsubscript𝐺𝜇𝜈superscript𝜅2𝑉subscript𝑔𝜇𝜈0012𝑅4superscript𝜅2𝑉superscript𝑔12E_{\Gamma\,IJ}=\begin{pmatrix}-G_{\mu\nu}-\kappa^{2}Vg_{\mu\nu}&0\\ 0&\frac{1}{2}(R-4\kappa^{2}V)\\ \end{pmatrix}|g|^{1/2}, (94)

where Gμ​ν+κ2​V​gμ​ν=0subscript𝐺𝜇𝜈superscript𝜅2𝑉subscript𝑔𝜇𝜈0G_{\mu\nu}+\kappa^{2}Vg_{\mu\nu}=0 is the Einstein equation when ϕitalic-ϕ\phi is constant. Note that the gauge and the scalar components of the operator all have a mass term containing mW2+R/2superscriptsubscript𝑚𝑊2𝑅2m_{W}^{2}+R/2 when the different contributions are added together.

The scaling behaviour of the one-loop action can be found as before by taking the spacetime background to be the Euclidean four-sphere. An important new consideration for the gauge boson beta-functions is the Higgs field wave function renormalisation at one loop,

16​π2​γϕ=−34​gtot2+O​(κ4​V0)16superscript𝜋2subscript𝛾italic-ϕ34superscriptsubscript𝑔tot2𝑂superscript𝜅4subscript𝑉016\pi^{2}\gamma_{\phi}=-\frac{3}{4}g_{\rm tot}^{2}+O(\kappa^{4}V_{0}) (95)

where gtot2=3​g2+g′⁣2superscriptsubscript𝑔tot23superscript𝑔2superscript𝑔′2g_{\rm tot}^{2}=3g^{2}+g^{\prime 2}. The leading term is simply the flat space result in Landau gauge. The absence of contributions at order κ2superscript𝜅2\kappa^{2} can be seen from relation (24), which expresses the difference between covariant and non-covariant results in terms of a tensor polynomial f𝑓f depending on the operator and the background field Einstein equation (55),

μR​∂ℒ∂μR−μR​∂ℒn​c∂μR=f×[κ2​(∇ϕ)2+4​κ2​V−R]subscript𝜇𝑅ℒsubscript𝜇𝑅subscript𝜇𝑅subscriptℒ𝑛𝑐subscript𝜇𝑅𝑓delimited-[]superscript𝜅2superscript∇italic-ϕ24superscript𝜅2𝑉𝑅\mu_{R}{\partial{\cal L}\over\partial\mu_{R}}-\mu_{R}{\partial{\cal L}_{nc}\over\partial\mu_{R}}=f\times\left[\kappa^{2}(\nabla\phi)^{2}+4\kappa^{2}V-R\right] (96)

The only constant in the operator (90) which could contribute to f𝑓f is μ2superscript𝜇2\mu^{2}. This would give a κ2​μ2​(∇ϕ)2superscript𝜅2superscript𝜇2superscript∇italic-ϕ2\kappa^{2}\mu^{2}(\nabla\phi)^{2} term, but this is of order κ4​V0superscript𝜅4subscript𝑉0\kappa^{4}V_{0} given our assumptions about μ2superscript𝜇2\mu^{2}.

Results are given in tables 3 and 4. The covariant beta-functions are independent of frame, and differ from the non-covariant expressions. As before, the two approaches agree on the combination which is important for Higgs stability, μ2+4​κ2​V0​ξsuperscript𝜇24superscript𝜅2subscript𝑉0𝜉\mu^{2}+4\kappa^{2}V_{0}\xi. There are differences in the sixth order coupling λ6subscript𝜆6\lambda_{6}, but this only enters the Higgs field equations at O​(κ4​V0)𝑂superscript𝜅4subscript𝑉0O(\kappa^{4}V_{0}).

We finish of with the top quark as an example of a fermion field. It is far from clear how the covariant approach generalises to fermion fields, so we take the minimalist approach and leave off any extra contributions to the effective action. The results are then checked for consistency against the covariant beta function relations (48-50). The beta functions are old results, but we repeat them here for completeness. The rescaling behaviour of the effective action due to the quark field is

μR​d​ΓE(1)d​μR=3​ζ​(0,−∇2+mt2+14​R),subscript𝜇𝑅𝑑subscriptsuperscriptΓ1𝐸𝑑subscript𝜇𝑅3𝜁0superscript∇2superscriptsubscript𝑚𝑡214𝑅\mu_{R}{d\Gamma^{(1)}_{E}\over d\mu_{R}}=3\,\zeta\left(0,-\nabla^{2}+m_{t}^{2}+\frac{1}{4}R\right), (97)

where mt=y​ϕ/2subscript𝑚𝑡𝑦italic-ϕ2m_{t}=y\phi/\sqrt{2} is the top quark mass and ∇μsubscript∇𝜇\nabla_{\mu} is the covariant derivative acting on Dirac fields. Fermion fields take the positive sign and the pre-factor takes into account the three colours of the S​U​(3)𝑆𝑈3SU(3) gauge group. With such a simple operator it is best to use general results for the adiabatic expansion coefficients Vassilevich:2003xt ,

b2​(−∇2+E)=2​(E−16​R)2+O​(R2),subscript𝑏2superscript∇2𝐸2superscript𝐸16𝑅2𝑂superscript𝑅2b_{2}(-\nabla^{2}+E)=2\left(E-\frac{1}{6}R\right)^{2}+O(R^{2}), (98)

The wave-function renormalisation at one loop is 16​π2​γϕ=3​y216superscript𝜋2subscript𝛾italic-ϕ3superscript𝑦216\pi^{2}\gamma_{\phi}=3y^{2}. The beta functions inferred from the renormalisation group equation (2) are,

16​π2​βξ16superscript𝜋2subscript𝛽𝜉\displaystyle 16\pi^{2}\beta_{\xi}\ =\displaystyle= (6​ξ−1)​y2,6𝜉1superscript𝑦2\displaystyle(6\xi-1)y^{2}, (99)
16​π2​βμ216superscript𝜋2subscript𝛽superscript𝜇2\displaystyle 16\pi^{2}\beta_{\mu^{2}} =\displaystyle= 6​y2​μ2,6superscript𝑦2superscript𝜇2\displaystyle 6y^{2}\mu^{2}, (100)
16​π2​βλ16superscript𝜋2subscript𝛽𝜆\displaystyle 16\pi^{2}\beta_{\lambda}\ =\displaystyle= −6​y4+12​λ​y2.6superscript𝑦412𝜆superscript𝑦2\displaystyle-6y^{4}+12\lambda y^{2}. (101)

There is no contribution to β6subscript𝛽6\beta_{6} and γgsubscript𝛾𝑔\gamma_{g} at one loop order.

7 The effective potential and stability

We have argued that the most important contributions to the corrected Higgs potential are independent of the conformal frame and the stability analysis will be unambiguous as long as κ4​V0superscript𝜅4subscript𝑉0\kappa^{4}V_{0} is negligible. To see how this works out in practice, we will consider instanton induced Higgs vacuum decay during inflation. Higgs instability is caused by negative values of the Higgs quartic coupling λeffsubscript𝜆eff\lambda_{\rm eff} at large ϕitalic-ϕ\phi. The Higgs vacuum is protected by a potential barrier, but the present Higgs vacuum cannot survive a period of inflation if quantum fluctuations take the Higgs field through the potential barrier. A large, positive, value for μeff2superscriptsubscript𝜇eff2\mu_{\rm eff}^{2} is helpful because it reduces the vacuum tunnelling rate Espinosa:2007qp .

Perturbative fluctuations in the Higgs field on the scale of the horizon have a magnitude of order the expansion rate H𝐻H. The vacuum will decay very rapidly if these fluctuations are larger than the barrier width. If we denote the value of the field at the maximum of the potential by ϕbsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑏\phi_{b}, then rapid vacuum decay occurs for H>ϕb𝐻subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑏H>\phi_{b}. If H<ϕb𝐻subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑏H<\phi_{b}, and |V′′​(ϕb)|<4​H2superscript𝑉′′subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑏4superscript𝐻2|V^{\prime\prime}(\phi_{b})|<4H^{2}, then the main contribution to vacuum decay can be calculated using an instanton solution with the topology of a four-sphere and constant field ϕ=ϕbitalic-ϕsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑏\phi=\phi_{b} Hawking:1981fz . The instanton induced tunnelling rate ΓDsubscriptΓ𝐷\Gamma_{D} is given by

ΓD=A​e−B,subscriptΓ𝐷𝐴superscript𝑒𝐵\Gamma_{D}=Ae^{-B}, (102)

where the dominant effect is due to the exponent, given by the difference in action

B=SE​[ϕb]−SE​[0].𝐵subscript𝑆𝐸delimited-[]subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑏subscript𝑆𝐸delimited-[]0B=S_{E}[\phi_{b}]-S_{E}[0]. (103)

The pre-factor A𝐴A should be very roughly of order H4superscript𝐻4H^{4} on dimensional grounds, so that we can think of e−Bsuperscript𝑒𝐵e^{-B} as the decay rate per horizon volume per expansion time.

Consider a classical Higgs action which is given by the Euclidean Jordan frame Lagrangian,

ℒE=12​(∇ϕ)2+V​(ϕ)−1κ2​U​(ϕ)​R.subscriptℒ𝐸12superscript∇italic-ϕ2𝑉italic-ϕ1superscript𝜅2𝑈italic-ϕ𝑅{\cal L}_{E}=\frac{1}{2}(\nabla\phi)^{2}+V(\phi)-{1\over\kappa^{2}}U(\phi)R. (104)

The Einstein equation (55) applied to the instanton four-sphere gives U​R=4​κ2​V𝑈𝑅4superscript𝜅2𝑉UR=4\kappa^{2}V. The Lagrangian is constant, and we only need to multiply the Lagrangian by the volume of a four-sphere of radius 12/R12𝑅\sqrt{12/R} to get the classical action,

SE​[ϕ]=−24​π2​U2κ4​V.subscript𝑆𝐸delimited-[]italic-ϕ24superscript𝜋2superscript𝑈2superscript𝜅4𝑉S_{E}[\phi]=-{24\pi^{2}U^{2}\over\kappa^{4}V}. (105)

The same result can be obtained from the Einstein frame action with potential VE=V/U2subscript𝑉𝐸𝑉superscript𝑈2V_{E}=V/U^{2}. If we now truncate the difference in action (103) to O​(κ0)𝑂superscript𝜅0O(\kappa^{0}), as in Eqs. (39-41), then the contribution to the exponent is

B=24​π29​H4​[12​(μ2+12​H2​ξ)​ϕb2+14​λ​ϕb4].𝐵24superscript𝜋29superscript𝐻4delimited-[]12superscript𝜇212superscript𝐻2𝜉superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑏214𝜆superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑏4B={24\pi^{2}\over 9H^{4}}\left[\frac{1}{2}(\mu^{2}+12H^{2}\xi)\phi_{b}^{2}+\frac{1}{4}\lambda\phi_{b}^{4}\right]. (106)

H𝐻H is the vacuum expansion rate, 3​H2=κ2​V03superscript𝐻2superscript𝜅2subscript𝑉03H^{2}=\kappa^{2}V_{0}. The top of the potential barrier is determined by the scalar field equation Eq. (56), which is equivalent to

VE′​(ϕb)=0,superscriptsubscript𝑉𝐸′subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑏0V_{E}^{\prime}(\phi_{b})=0, (107)

Note that all the main features of vacuum decay are determined by the Einstein frame potential even when we start out in the Jordan frame. This approach was used to calculate tunnelling rates in Ref. Calmet:2017hja .

We will assume that the quantum corrections are taken into account by replacing the classical action in the tunnelling exponent with the renormalisation group corrected effective action,

B=ΓE​[ϕb]−ΓE​[0],𝐵subscriptΓ𝐸delimited-[]subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑏subscriptΓ𝐸delimited-[]0B=\Gamma_{E}[\phi_{b}]-\Gamma_{E}[0], (108)

where ΓEsubscriptΓ𝐸\Gamma_{E} uses the effective couplings. In particular,

Veff=12​μeff2​(ϕ)​ϕ2+14​λeff​(ϕ)​ϕ4subscript𝑉eff12superscriptsubscript𝜇eff2italic-ϕsuperscriptitalic-ϕ214subscript𝜆effitalic-ϕsuperscriptitalic-ϕ4V_{\rm eff}=\frac{1}{2}\mu_{\rm eff}^{2}(\phi)\phi^{2}+\frac{1}{4}\lambda_{\rm eff}(\phi)\phi^{4} (109)

where μeff2superscriptsubscript𝜇eff2\mu_{\rm eff}^{2} is the combination μeff2=μ2+12​ξ​H2superscriptsubscript𝜇eff2superscript𝜇212𝜉superscript𝐻2\mu_{\rm eff}^{2}=\mu^{2}+12\xi H^{2}. The couplings are obtained by solving the renormalisation group equations (3).

Initial conditions for the running couplings are set at some chosen point. We take this point to be ϕ=170​G​e​Vitalic-ϕ170GeV\phi=170{\rm GeV}, close to the top quark mass. Combining the results from the tables of beta functions and replacing the vacuum energy by the expansion rate H𝐻H gives

16​π2​d​μeff2d​t=12​(μeff2−2​H2)​λ−12​(μeff2−6​H2)​gtot2+6​(μeff2−2​H2)​y2,16superscript𝜋2𝑑superscriptsubscript𝜇eff2𝑑𝑡12superscriptsubscript𝜇eff22superscript𝐻2𝜆12superscriptsubscript𝜇eff26superscript𝐻2superscriptsubscript𝑔tot26superscriptsubscript𝜇eff22superscript𝐻2superscript𝑦216\pi^{2}{d\mu_{\rm eff}^{2}\over dt}=12\left(\mu_{\rm eff}^{2}-2H^{2}\right)\lambda-\frac{1}{2}\left(\mu_{\rm eff}^{2}-6H^{2}\right)g_{\rm tot}^{2}+6\left(\mu_{\rm eff}^{2}-2H^{2}\right)y^{2}, (110)

The value of the Higgs coupling is known from experiments at energies less than 1​T​e​V1TeV1{\rm TeV}. The best available values of the Higgs and top quark masses imply that λ​(170​G​e​V)=0.12577𝜆170GeV0.12577\lambda(170{\rm GeV})=0.12577 Degrassi:2012ry . These experiments are essentially at zero vacuum energy V0≈0subscript𝑉00V_{0}\approx 0, but since there is no dependence on the vacuum energy V0subscript𝑉0V_{0} in βλsubscript𝛽𝜆\beta_{\lambda}, we can take the experimental values over to the early universe where V0subscript𝑉0V_{0} is large.

The value of μ2superscript𝜇2\mu^{2} for the Higgs field as determined in the laboratory is negligible compared to the value of ξ​R𝜉𝑅\xi R in the inflationary universe, but here we have to take care because of subtleties in the properties of light fields in de Sitter space Weinberg:2005vy . We already see a hint of this in the covariant beta-function which is large, of order H2/3superscript𝐻23H^{2}/3. In the Euclidean approach to quantum field theory, the infra-red problems lead to a breakdown of perturbation theory for μeff2≲λ1/2​H2less-than-or-similar-tosuperscriptsubscript𝜇eff2superscript𝜆12superscript𝐻2\mu_{\rm eff}^{2}\lesssim\lambda^{1/2}H^{2} Beneke:2012kn , so our treatment will only be valid above this bound. Stochastic approximations imply that the light Higgs field develops a mass μeff2≈0.3534​λ1/2​H2superscriptsubscript𝜇eff20.3534superscript𝜆12superscript𝐻2\mu_{\rm eff}^{2}\approx 0.3534\lambda^{1/2}H^{2} Starobinsky:1994bd ; Garbrecht:2011gu ; Beneke:2012kn ; Moss:2016uix . If we assume μ2​(170​G​e​V)≪H2much-less-thansuperscript𝜇2170GeVsuperscript𝐻2\mu^{2}(170{\rm GeV})\ll H^{2}, then this sets a lower limit for de Sitter space of ξ​(170​G​e​V)>0.029​λ1/2𝜉170GeV0.029superscript𝜆12\xi(170{\rm GeV})>0.029\lambda^{1/2}. We can say nothing about curvature couplings smaller than this because the techniques required for dealing with loop corrections with smaller effective mass scales are quite different from the ones we use here Weinberg:2005vy ; Kahya:2007bc .

The effective couplings using (110) are plotted in Fig. 1. The standard model couplings λ𝜆\lambda, g𝑔g, g′superscript𝑔′g^{\prime} and y𝑦y have been evolved simultaneously using the two-loop flat space beta functions given in Espinosa:2007qp . The value of the top quark mass mtsubscript𝑚𝑡m_{t} sets the scale of the Yukawa coupling y𝑦y and this has a significant effect on the running of the Higgs self-coupling, and the value of the field where λ𝜆\lambda vanishes. (The location of the point λ=0𝜆0\lambda=0 is not fixed very accurately by the renormalisation group corrected potential, and other two loop effects ought to be included. We have corrected for this by raising λ​(170​G​e​V)𝜆170GeV\lambda(170{\rm GeV}) by 0.2%.)

Note that for small initial values, the effective mass becomes negative at Higgs field values below the Planck scale. This can further drive the Higgs instability, and it can even give the potential a second maximum. This is illustrated by the potential plots in Fig. 2. A combination of small initial μeff2superscriptsubscript𝜇eff2\mu_{\rm eff}^{2} and small expansion rate H𝐻H leads to twin maxima.

The Higgs effective potential has been used to find the tunnelling exponents plotted in Fig. 3. The two plots show different values of the top quark mass, the first one closest in line with the measured value and the second which favours Higgs stability. The results are plotted against the expansion rate of the Higgs vacuum H𝐻H and the value of the curvature coupling at 170​G​e​V170GeV170{\rm GeV}, under the assumption that the Higgs mass square μ2superscript𝜇2\mu^{2} is negligible at small ϕitalic-ϕ\phi. (This latter assumption is questionable, because only the combination μeff2superscriptsubscript𝜇eff2\mu_{\rm eff}^{2} has a frame independent meaning when the non-covariant methodology is adopted.)

In the parameter region ξ<0.022𝜉0.022\xi<0.022 the potential has two maxima. Inside this region, the tunnelling rate is evaluated at the larger maximum. It is sometimes possible for the Higgs field to tunnel to the lower maximum, roll down the potential, and then tunnel up to the larger maximum. This combination is less likely than the single tunnelling event, and has no effect on the stability of the parameter region at the bottom of figure 3. However, for small curvature coupling, the field could become trapped between the two maxima during inflation, and return to the present vacuum state after inflation.

The results support the idea first, proposed in Ref. Espinosa:2007qp , that Higgs stability is sensitive to the value of the curvature coupling, though there are caveats concerning the case of negative ξ𝜉\xi, as mentioned above. Running couplings were included in the Higgs stability analysis of Herranen:2014cua . The results are consistent with Herranen:2014cua , although our results are more precise. Our main conclusion is that the stability analysis is independent of the choice of Jordan or Einstein frame.

Exactly how we interpret Fig. 3 is dependent on what we understand by the inflationary scenario. Suppose first of all that the universe is unique, with the minimum amount of inflation of around N=60𝑁60N=60 e-folds. The universe would then have started out one de Sitter horizon length across, and have grown to include e3​Nsuperscript𝑒3𝑁e^{3N} de Sitter horizon regions at the end of inflation. The majority of these had to survive Higgs vacuum decay, leading to an extreme limit B≳180greater-than-or-equivalent-to𝐵180B\gtrsim 180.

In the event that there are many universes like ours, then the conclusion is quite different because only one out of many universes has to survive Higgs vacuum decay. Espinosa et al. Espinosa:2007qp argued that the survival probability of the universe can be calculated and should be ∝exp⁡(−H2​N/32​ϕb2)proportional-toabsentsuperscript𝐻2𝑁32superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑏2\propto\exp(-H^{2}N/32\phi_{b}^{2}). Assuming that the survival probability of our universe should be not be exponentially small gives a lower limit on the field at the top of the potential barrier ϕb≳H​N1/2greater-than-or-equivalent-tosubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑏𝐻superscript𝑁12\phi_{b}\gtrsim HN^{1/2}. This condition can be expressed in terms of B𝐵B, for if we substitute this into Eq. (106), then

B≳π224​μeff2H2​N.greater-than-or-equivalent-to𝐵superscript𝜋224superscriptsubscript𝜇eff2superscript𝐻2𝑁B\gtrsim{\pi^{2}\over 24}{\mu_{\rm eff}^{2}\over H^{2}}N. (111)

In practice μeff2/H2∼1similar-tosuperscriptsubscript𝜇eff2superscript𝐻21\mu_{\rm eff}^{2}/H^{2}\sim 1, and therefore ϕb≳H​N1/2greater-than-or-equivalent-tosubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑏𝐻superscript𝑁12\phi_{b}\gtrsim HN^{1/2} corresponds very roughly to B≳Ngreater-than-or-equivalent-to𝐵𝑁B\gtrsim N.

8 Conclusion

The Higgs-gravity system provides an interesting laboratory for trying out ideas in quantum gravity. One of the issues quantum gravity raises is how to define the spacetime geometry when scalar and metric backgrounds are allowed to mix freely together. We have found that applying a methodology which is fully covariant under such field redefinitions is perfectly feasible. This allows a complete physical equivalence between the different conformal frames. On the other hand, non-covariant approaches can still be used on scales below the Planck mass as long as we are careful. We advocate using the effective mass μ2+ξ​Rsuperscript𝜇2𝜉𝑅\mu^{2}+\xi R, since this has a covariant meaning, and the simpler Einstein frame can always be used. In particular, we have found that it is always possible to work consistently in a frame in which the curvature coupling vanishes. The dependence on curvature coupling in other frames can be recovered from relations like the beta function relations given in Sect. 3

The effective action calculations we have done allow quite detailed results for Higgs vacuum decay which take into account running coupling constants, expanding on the work in Herranen:2014cua . As previously stated Espinosa:2007qp , the Higgs-curvature coupling can raise the potential barrier around the Higgs vacuum and stabilise the Higgs field during inflation. There are some caveats here, such as the extra metastable minima in the Higgs potential for small curvature coupling, and infra-red effects which set a lower bound to the effective Higgs mass, which deserve further study.

In one respect, the approach adopted has not been as general as it could, and maybe should, be. The covariant effective action has been used, but field redefinitions have not been fully integrated with the renormalisation group. In a fully general treatment, the renormalised field ϕR=Z​(μR)​ϕsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑅𝑍subscript𝜇𝑅italic-ϕ\phi_{R}=Z(\mu_{R})\phi should become a non-linear mapping into field space, ϕR=ϕR​(ϕ,μR)subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑅subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑅italic-ϕsubscript𝜇𝑅\phi_{R}=\phi_{R}(\phi,\mu_{R}). We have have not attempted this, in order to retain as much familiarity with conventional renormalisation group methods as possible.

Finally, we should point out that we have used existing non-covariant results for the standard model beta functions which are not associated with the spacetime curvature. This could cause problems if the running couplings depend on gauge parameters. In fact, the ‘g2​λsuperscript𝑔2𝜆g^{2}\lambda’ terms in βλsubscript𝛽𝜆\beta_{\lambda} are dependent on gauge parameters ParkerTomsbook . The field value at which the quartic Higgs coupling become negative is not protected by any Nielsen identities and may well be gauge parameter dependent. We think that may be something to learn from gauge-parameter dependence for Higgs instability in flat space.

Appendix B Zeta-function evaluation

Generalised zeta-functions for the operator eigenvalues on a four-sphere can be evaluated by using a standard binomial expansion method Dowker:1993ww ; Elizalde:1994gf . Eigenvalues of the Laplacian are quadratic in n𝑛n, but after diagonalisation of our operators some of the eigenvalues are non-polynomial, and a modification of the usual techniques is required.

We start with the Laplacian eigenvalues,

λSsubscript𝜆𝑆\displaystyle\lambda_{S} =\displaystyle= R12​[(n+32)2−94]𝑅12delimited-[]superscript𝑛32294\displaystyle\frac{R}{12}\left[\left(n+\frac{3}{2}\right)^{2}-\frac{9}{4}\right] (120)
λVsubscript𝜆𝑉\displaystyle\lambda_{V} =\displaystyle= R12​[(n+52)2−134]𝑅12delimited-[]superscript𝑛522134\displaystyle\frac{R}{12}\left[\left(n+\frac{5}{2}\right)^{2}-\frac{13}{4}\right] (121)
λTsubscript𝜆𝑇\displaystyle\lambda_{T} =\displaystyle= R12​[(n+72)2−174]𝑅12delimited-[]superscript𝑛722174\displaystyle\frac{R}{12}\left[\left(n+\frac{7}{2}\right)^{2}-\frac{17}{4}\right] (122)

The degeneracies of these eigenvalues are

gSsubscript𝑔𝑆\displaystyle g_{S} =\displaystyle= 13​(n+32)3−112​(n+32)13superscript𝑛323112𝑛32\displaystyle\frac{1}{3}\left(n+\frac{3}{2}\right)^{3}-\frac{1}{12}\left(n+\frac{3}{2}\right) (124)
gVsubscript𝑔𝑉\displaystyle g_{V} =\displaystyle= (n+52)3−94​(n+52)superscript𝑛52394𝑛52\displaystyle\left(n+\frac{5}{2}\right)^{3}-\frac{9}{4}\left(n+\frac{5}{2}\right) (125)
gTsubscript𝑔𝑇\displaystyle g_{T} =\displaystyle= 53​(n+72)3−12512​(n+72)53superscript𝑛72312512𝑛72\displaystyle\frac{5}{3}\left(n+\frac{7}{2}\right)^{3}-\frac{125}{12}\left(n+\frac{7}{2}\right) (126)

The eigenvalues λnsubscript𝜆𝑛\lambda_{n} obtained after diagonalisation are algebraic functions of these eigenvalues which can be expanded for large n𝑛n as power series

λn=112​R​[(n+a)2+A+B​(n+a)−2+…].subscript𝜆𝑛112𝑅delimited-[]superscript𝑛𝑎2𝐴𝐵superscript𝑛𝑎2…\lambda_{n}=\frac{1}{12}R\left[(n+a)^{2}+A+B(n+a)^{-2}+\dots\right]. (128)

The degeneracies are generally

gn=b​(n+a)3+c​(n+a).subscript𝑔𝑛𝑏superscript𝑛𝑎3𝑐𝑛𝑎g_{n}=b(n+a)^{3}+c(n+a). (129)

We replace λn−ssuperscriptsubscript𝜆𝑛𝑠\lambda_{n}^{-s} in the zeta-function by its binomial expansion, and then sums of powers of n+a𝑛𝑎n+a can be replaced with Hurwitz zeta-functions ζH​(s,a)subscript𝜁𝐻𝑠𝑎\zeta_{H}(s,a),

ζH​(s,a)=∑n=0∞(n+a)−s.subscript𝜁𝐻𝑠𝑎superscriptsubscript𝑛0superscript𝑛𝑎𝑠\zeta_{H}(s,a)=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}(n+a)^{-s}. (130)

The Hurwitz zeta-functions have an analytic extension with a pole at s=0𝑠0s=0 with residue 1. Values at s=−1𝑠1s=-1 and s=−3𝑠3s=-3 are Bernoulli polynomials,

ζ​(−1,a)=−12​B2​(a),ζ​(−3,a)=−14​B4​(a)formulae-sequence𝜁1𝑎12subscript𝐵2𝑎𝜁3𝑎14subscript𝐵4𝑎\zeta(-1,a)=-\frac{1}{2}B_{2}(a),\quad\zeta(-3,a)=-\frac{1}{4}B_{4}(a) (131)

After rearranging the summations we arrive at an expression for the zeta function,

ζ​(s)=(R12)−s​{b​f​(s)+c​g​(s)},𝜁𝑠superscript𝑅12𝑠𝑏𝑓𝑠𝑐𝑔𝑠\zeta(s)=\left({R\over 12}\right)^{-s}\{bf(s)+cg(s)\}, (132)

where

f​(s)𝑓𝑠\displaystyle f(s) =\displaystyle= ζH​(2​s−3,a)−s​B​ζH​(2​s+1,a)+12​s​(s+1)​A2​ζH​(2​s+1,a)+…subscript𝜁𝐻2𝑠3𝑎𝑠𝐵subscript𝜁𝐻2𝑠1𝑎12𝑠𝑠1superscript𝐴2subscript𝜁𝐻2𝑠1𝑎…\displaystyle\zeta_{H}(2s-3,a)-sB\zeta_{H}(2s+1,a)+\frac{1}{2}s(s+1)A^{2}\zeta_{H}(2s+1,a)+\dots (133)
g​(s)𝑔𝑠\displaystyle g(s) =\displaystyle= ζH​(2​s−1,a)−s​A​ζH​(2​s+1,a)+…subscript𝜁𝐻2𝑠1𝑎𝑠𝐴subscript𝜁𝐻2𝑠1𝑎…\displaystyle\zeta_{H}(2s-1,a)-sA\zeta_{H}(2s+1,a)+\dots (134)

All of the terms denoted by ……\dots vanish at s=0𝑠0s=0 and we are left with

ζ​(0)=−12​c​B2​(a)−14​b​B4​(a)−c2​A−b4​(2​B−A2).𝜁012𝑐subscript𝐵2𝑎14𝑏subscript𝐵4𝑎𝑐2𝐴𝑏42𝐵superscript𝐴2\zeta(0)=-\frac{1}{2}cB_{2}(a)-\frac{1}{4}bB_{4}(a)-{c\over 2}A-{b\over 4}(2B-A^{2}). (135)

The zeta-function sum is always taken from n=0𝑛0n=0, but some of the derived modes are identically zero for some n𝑛n. For example, the gradient of a constant scalar mode does not give a valid vector mode. These exceptions are handled by subtracting the contributions from the N​(h)𝑁ℎN(h) non-existent modes,

ζ​(0)=(∑n=0∞gn​λn−s)s=0−N​(h)𝜁0subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑛0subscript𝑔𝑛superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑛𝑠𝑠0𝑁ℎ\zeta(0)=\left(\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}g_{n}\lambda_{n}^{-s}\right)_{s=0}-N(h) (136)

In particular,

N​(∇μhS)=1,N​(∇(μhν)V)=10,N​(∇μ​νhS)=6,N(\nabla_{\mu}h^{S})=1,\quad N(\nabla_{(\mu}h^{V}_{\nu)})=10,\quad N(\nabla_{\mu\nu}h^{S})=6, (137)

the last factor consisting of one n=0𝑛0n=0 and five n=1𝑛1n=1 scalar modes with vanishing second derivative.
